column8:
Some classes have nice accommodations due to being remote - like a few late extensions without penalty, midterm exam windows that are not tight. Stat110 last semester is a great example of this last semester

However many classes do not. They are handled nearly exactly the same as if we were on campus. Harsh deadlines to the minute where you get zero if you don't make it in time. In a virtual uncertain environment, this should not be the case. Classes should be more lenient and this would improve mental health. An example of this is Neuro 115.

column11:
I want to get back to campus.

I want to be able to live normally upon receiving the vaccine. As a 21 year-old, there is no reason why I cannot go to a social event without masks or social distancing once inoculated against the virus. I would be very disappointed if I came back to campus to find that Harvard maintains these sorts of intense restrictions (all virtual classes, frequent COVID testing, dorm lockdowns, etc.) for those who have had the vaccine. I would hope that Harvard makes preparations to guarantee access to the vaccine for its whole faculty and student population to foster a return to normalcy. If I get some email from Dean Khurana entitled "A New Schoolyear and a New Normal" or something to that effect, I will have no choice but to cheer for Yale instead.
column31:
I like the concept of extended pass fail deadlines generally. With the normal P/F deadline, you rarely have enough work done in your classes to figure out where your grade is for Pass-Failing.

I'm also not going to turn down the opportunity to spend $5000 on Harvard's dime. Make it $10,000 if you want; I'll happily take it.

Please make sure that vaccinated Harvard students are able to live normally. The existing measures make sense for people who do not have the vaccine, but the fact of the matter is that Harvard's student base is young and healthy. Even the professors will be largely safe after getting the vaccine. The end stage of this virus is that we will have to live with it-- like the flu or common cold. We don't shut down campus and ruin the college experience over those. I would hope that a combination of baseless fear and virtue signaling does not require people to sacrifice another year of education, mental health, working opportunities, and personal development. 

Other colleges are fully open with minimal COVID consequences. I think they moved too quickly. But now we have to get with the times.
column35: It's no on-campus experience for sure, but professors have done quite well adapting. Sometimes it's easy to get distracted in another tab and undercut yourself. column11: I know not all traditions can return, but it would be nice to be able to attend at least one sports event (outside) or let club sports play again (local teams and outside). I also would be completely fine with just in person house graduation (no Yard graduation). I would also like to live on campus again for the whole year.
column31: Some sections and labs offered in person, but with virtual options for those that cannot return to campus and all lectures remaining online. There shouldn't be fully in person offerings until everyone (including internationals and immunocompromised) can return safely to campus. It makes sense to have us move out around thanksgiving to avoid peak holiday travel spread issues, but standard fall breaks should still be followed. Vaccinations probably could be required, but offer vaccines to those who haven't been able to get it yet (and be aware of students who want to return to campus but cannot get the vaccine due to well documented health reasons). Sports should be able to return, but they should be with local teams that also follow rigorous testing/isolation standards and should be outside/in rooms with open windows whenever possible. Clubs should still operate mostly virtually, with any in person offerings acting as enhancements so no one feels left out.

column31: I cannot take in-person classes because of fear to my family and those with autoimmune disorders who cannot fully get the vaccine. I think that everything, included lab and section and lecture, should still be fully online or those who don't want to come back should be given the opportunity to take things fully online. I do not expect fall 2021 to be a true and safe return to normal for people in my situations, and for many students. And as such, I believe we should have the opportunity to continue with online 100%. And even if we turn to campus, I fully believe that I will not want to be doing anything in-person for this very reason. I, and a lot of students, would rather stay at home and continue with online rather than being forced to in-person classes if we have to return, which I think is truly unfair. All students should be given the option to continue with fully online or not, and then classes can be divided up based on those options.

If we are forced into anything in-person, like lab, section, and lecture, than I will not return to on-campus. But if we are given the option to do like a hybrid plan or a fully online experience, then I would pick the online experience and return to campus with safety as my main concern.

column9:
Allow students of other Houses in House common rooms in the Level Lime, and have the common rooms open for more than a couple hours just on weekdays! As someone who has most of her friends in other houses, and thus won't really be using the common room / dining hall to see people, it was disheartening to see that Lime was basically the same as Yellow. It's especially frustrating given that there's such a huge gap between Lime and Green, so we're unlikely to hit Green anytime soon, and I'm not sure why it's a big deal to allow students of other Houses in the common room under a capacity limit if we can have them in our suites.

Also, I'd have made the wellness days all Mondays/Fridays, and had some Tuesdays/Wed/Thursdays follow Monday/Friday schedules. When the wellness days are next to weekends, they feel more meaningful.
column11: Ability to eat in / socialize in the dining hall, have some small sections / office hours in person, and have larger (10) groups in common rooms, even if we're still masked! I'd also like to see the administration stop condescending to us so much (e.g. "online school isn't harder; it's just different!") and acknowledge we are losing these college rites of passage, and though there are much bigger COVID-19 problems, we're allowed to be upset about that loss.

column31:
Less severe punishments for restriction violations. Sending someone home for hanging out with three other students??? That is draconian and completely unbecoming of a residential college such as Harvard. 

As for the restrictions themselves, they ought to be lighter. Students should not be discouraged from seeing one another. The truth is that many social hangouts demand more than a few people! This should not be penalized, let alone over a year and a half into the pandemic with most students vaccinated. These restrictions-- not that the college should enact any-- should not meddle with what I would call "day to day" hanging out. If they are going to crack down on anything, it should be events with 300+ people. A party at the 10-man, or Igloo, for example, should not be subject to restrictions.
column32: Discontinue online events. Return to how it was pre-covid.
column35:
I came to harvard for the people primarily. I have met 0 people in the last 13 months. I have made no new friends. If anything, my existing friendships have deteriorated greatly. I have been alone because harvard did not invite my grade back to campus. One's satisfaction with their education waxes and wanes; I understand that. There were periods of up and down in high school, as well as pre-covid at Harvard my freshman year. But there was always the opportunity to meet new people, join a new club, or engage in fun activities and socializing. This year has been awful. While Covid has reduced everyone's experience, in higher education and beyond, I blame the College itself 95% for my awful year. Given that 1) covid rarely affects people my age in serious ways and 2) Harvard has tremendous resources to keep people safe, I feel that there is no excuse to not have had all four classes on campus, in both the fall and spring. What's more, the fall say a miniscule positive test rate! And this still did not motivate the planning committee to invite more than 2 grades back in the spring! The fall was billed as an experiment; it went great. And yet the spring plan barely reflected such a roaring success! The 2020-2021 academic year is a black eye that my fellow Sophomores and I will not soon forget. Our college's decision was as unsympathetic to the Sophomore experience as possible. There is no feasible way in which the decisions made for 2020-2021 could have been less generous to our grade. We were totally online-- in what additional ways could one have reduced our experience? Besides banning us from zoom -- which hardly would have changed my own happiness, considering zoom is a joke-- I can't think of any. 

I consider the treatment of the sophomores to be shameful. I have not a single positive thing to say about the planning of the 2020-2021 academic year. Never before has a "virtual" call been considered a social event in the vein of, say, going out to dinner with friends. Yet the planning committee considers it to be a near-equal mimic of in-person events-- it's not. 

The planning committee, with respect to its hesitancy to invite students on-campus and allow for fun to transpire rule-and-punishment free, has this year put on a master class in uncreative planning, cowardly decision-making, and dereliction of duty. It is a difficult thing to damper the excitement and cheer of 20-something-year old college students. But my congratulations to the people in charge of planning the 2020-2021 academic year: you have achieved what I thought impossible. 

Covid poses a tall task for any coordinator of logistics. But instead of rising up to the challenge, those in charge have decided to lay down, whimper, and their wrists in submission, and then sacrifice the Class of 2023 for the amusement of the beast.

column8:
'-The house life is extremely bad, there is almost no genuine attempt at programming.
-The food is atrociously bad in the houses, people were already unhappy with HUDS and now it is even worse. The food is not accessible to those with non-life-threatening food restrictions and it is extremely unhealthy.
-The wellness days program is not really working well, instructors do not take it seriously at all. I had to do work on all my wellness days because my instructors included the day in exam windows, and some others completely disregarded it and scheduled office hours, sections and meetings.
-The houses don't have printers, which makes it very difficult to print class-related documents as we have to travel to printing shops like Gnomon Copy, especially from the quad.
-The shuttle system is really disorganized and the evening vans are inaccessible when they are needed the most.
-Certain departments have completely abandoned their support systems and left their students alone to figure things out on their own.
-Professors are not on the same page about how this time in our lives may require us to ask for adjustments, section moves and extensions. While some are very understanding, some others have even a stricter policy.
-A great number of classes increased their class time through pre-recorded lectures on top of live ones because students are doing them remotely, and a lot of them did not make this transparent in their syllabi.
column9: HUDS has to be reformed in a way that there is a partial opt-in/out system for those who are just sick and tired of eating mediocre food for $3500.

With working being so difficult for students in COVID, this would be a great way to support low-income students.

column8: Biggest factor is being on campus with a lot of other seniors and living with my closest friends in a suite. It's been really really nice to hang out with friends and not be home, a stressful place for me.
column9: I would relax the reservation system for using music rooms and Beren rooftop for Winthrop, as well as open the junior/senior common rooms for study usage. The reservation system is inconvenient because these spaces are open only 9am-4pm Monday-Friday, which is when most people have classes, meetings, or meal time. So opening these spaces is meaningless. I think usage of these spaces even without the barrier of the reservation system is low anyway (I've never run into another person in the music rooms or beren rooftop), so I don't think it'd be like "opening the floodgates" by relaxing restrictions here.
column12:
I hope that Harvard would let us stay in the dorms and provide food free of charge for those who were on 100% financial aid and lower cost for the rest of students. It'd be great if the graduation were also longer than a single day -- perhaps a 4 day weekend event or weeklong celebration for those who can make it -- in order to make up for our missed Senior Week.

One note: I'm on the fence as to whether everyone should wear regalia or not. I think it'd be cool to do the walk into Tercentenary Theater with our houses, but wearing graduation gowns so long after graduation would feel odd/silly.

In addition, I hope that the graduation ceremony occurs as soon as possible. The longer we wait, I think the harder it would be to have a good time with people whom we've been out-of-touch with for a while. For example, ceremonies next summer for the classes of 2020 and 2021 (separately) would be so much more fulfilling than having ceremonies the year after or even later. At that point, the ceremony would just be an alumni reunion.
column31: A lot more reopening of common spaces, especially within houses. More house-sponsored outdoor social events, like friendly sports games. (bring back IMs!)
column35: Small classes have translated over really well, but classes of 70+ students are really hard to make engaging over Zoom. Also, it's a lot harder to ask friends for help on psets or when studying for tests in remote school, especially when you don't know anyone in a class (which is the typical situation).
column38:
Online learning is more challenging not because the course material is different, but because it's hard to come to class emotionally engaged. I believe that emotion is a huge aspect of learning, and it's difficult to feel any emotional connection to course content without feeling the pulse of a room and watching people's body language.

I also wish that grading rules were changed to reflect unique challenges of COVID-19. Last semester, I had to take on 10+ hours/week of housekeeping and caretaking duties for my family while living at home, and I felt really disadvantaged in having to maintain my extracurriculars as well as GPA while some other students had comfortable situations at home. Extra housework has made me more burnt out than I've ever been, and it's carried over into this spring semester. Nowadays, I don't feel like doing anything at all, but I just grit my teeth and do my work anyway.
column40: Remote school = no social life. Zoom catch-ups don't make up for actually doing things together on campus. Playing games with other people through Zoom is a lot more fun, but I don't have a friend group per se and most online games require 4+ people. I wish that the Houses sponsored a lot more Zoom game nights or outdoor games because just talking to people is tiring.
column41: Having guests over in rooms is EXTREMELY important. Next, I'd say opening common spaces (gyms, house spaces, house gyms, etc.). Then in-person House events like Winthrop's Music & Mingle. Then dining halls and small classes.
column44: I'm a senior graduating this May so I didn't know how to answer the above question

column11: In-person graduation :'( ripppppppp
column31: If we will be made to leave campus prior to Thansgiving, then the semester ought to end prior to Thanksgiving (perhaps maybe just exam week following Thansgiving, but no additional classes). Changing our living situation while also trying to juggle the inevitable glut of work  that comes at the end of a semester (final papers, projects, studying for exams) AND also transitioning to an online format while going to final lectures feels a bit insane, and is extremely stressful for students.
column32: I still prefer spring break over wellness days. HOWEVER, one thing I have noticed is that only the most audacious of professors (yes, there still are a few) will make their students turn in homework, attend class, or work on a test over a wellness day. Wellness days have become somewhat sacrosanct. The same cannot be said of spring break. Professors like to trod all over it and aasign papers, homework, etc. willy nilly throughout this so-called "break". Spring break never felt like a break to me, just a semi-stressful time of no classes and lots of homework. That is just outright unhealthy, especially if the university wants to help its students mentally cope with stress. I'd love it if the College finally learned something from these wellness days and really implemented a no-loophole no-homework rule during spring break.
column35:
If you are lucky, you get a nice professor who is typically younger, more progressive, etc. and also cares greatly about the mental health of her students. She may make grading lighter, assign students less material, and make the course more engaging to help students cope with the unceasing stress a pandemic causes (I'm looking at you, Prof. Carla Martin - she is the best).
On the other hand, you have grumpier professors who do not understand the stress. "What's the big deal? They have so much time. They sit at their computers all day anyway, in their comfy houses, wearing pyjamas." This is the type of attitude that really hurts the culture of Harvard and the mental health of its students. The professor may grade as harshly (or MORE harshly) and assign students more work. It is actually a big problem. I'd love if the College was able to tell all the professors to chill out a bit so we students are not penalized for factors outside of our control, such as family stress, living situation, low income, etc which is only exacerbated by this pandemic.
column38: Talking, the sinplest communication, is so hard. Especially in my language class, it is impossible to know when to interject. Learning goes so slowly. It is easier to drift off - a computer screen is not fun to look at. Students don't need to be engaged. Cameras are off, mics muted. Sometimes feels like I'm watching edX courses on Youtube.
column40:
Obvious things, which are out of many people's control. 
1) Spontaneous interaction - I probably met 80% of my friends at Harvard (prior to this COVID mess) spontaneously. Socialization is basically impossible now. Nobody wants to go to another Zoom trivia night, our eyes hurt.
2) Orgs - why join a club if you can't really meet its members? If you can't participate in activities together? There are exceptions, obviously.
column41:

4) Open some study spaces! I like that Smith is open

column8: I have been satisfied with the fact that none of my professors have made work due on Wellness days (they actually expect and want us to take the day off). I have also appreciated how flexible they've been with my AEO accommodations, and with limited testing in general. I think it was a good call to place more emphasis grade-wise on participation, giving students credit for putting up with the sheer fatigue of being on zoom all the time.
column9: I don't think all students have been as lucky as I have been in regards to wellness days. Also I don't think it's fair of professors to assign extra work to take advantage of zoom. For example, I have a class where if we don't get through all the material the professor will just record the rest of it and expect us to find time to watch and take notes on it, and he has admitted that that is a benefit of being online, but it's little things like that that take advantage of the presumed ‚Äúextra time‚Äù students have to spend on zoom.
column13: I have close to zero house pride at the moment. What's worse is that I have a feeling that once we get on campus in the fall all the emphasis will be on the current freshmen who were just assigned houses, while us sophomores will be left behind. I understand that there have been opportunities to engage with my house online, but I have had no motivation to do so after spending hours on zoom and I know I'm not alone in that opinion. I just want to make sure there re sophomore-oriented (or I guess at that point junior-oriented) house events in the fall.
column31: As a sophomore who never got a chance to live with their blocking group, I would hope the opportunity to do so could happen, or at least to live in the same general ‚Äúpod‚Äù to gain that lost experience. I would like to continue to see frequent testing and mask wearing outside of individuals rooms (granted there could be exceptions for individuals in relationships, necessitating expanding bubbles).
column32: I like the emphasis on participation in our grades, rewarding students for their effort and not putting as much pressure on being right. This way we aren't stuck in modes of competing with our peers but learning from and with them. I also like the option of simultaneous enrollment that having classes online enables. I have a class that since I can't attend live I attend at night where TFs share their screen and lead a handful of students like me through the activities which is so much better than having to watch the videos on my own time without that support.
column35: My situation is different than most because I've been dealing with chronic illness symptoms in the midst of the pandemic, so to some extent I've actually benefitted from taking classes from my bedroom and the leniency of the professors as well. I have been living at home this semester and am very lucky that I have a home environment that is conducive to work. I know the administration has not come forth and said anything specific about this so it may not be true, but I do wish that I had known that on-campus living for freshman was not going to be as highly selective as I'd expected. Although I'm lucky to have a great home and family, I did feel socially isolated at home, especially seeing a lot of my friends grow their relationships without me.

column9: I would open it up to more people. Freshman definitely had their chance to be on campus in the fall, so it should've been seniors, juniors AND all sophomores. I think sophomores really got the "shortest straw" when it came to all the COVID policies.

I think it's going to be really interesting how the whole freshman class reacts to experiencing college for the first time, and as a sophmore.
column15: It was concerning at first (in like December and January) that I felt I didn't have many options for blocking groups. However, I realized that blocking groups really aren't that serious at the end of the day, and ultimately it turned out perfectly fine. The only change is just stop emphasizing how important the process is. I feel like Harvard makes this process seem like it's life-changing. Like choosing up to 7 people to be in the same house with is by no means a very consequential decision so that's the only thing I would've wanted.
column31: I would like to see the restriction on small gatherings lifted. I understand that huge groups (50+) may not be safe but definitely smaller gatherings should be allowed. Basically, I want to have a pseudo-normal year with in-person classes, club meetings, outings and dining with friends, etc. The only difference would be random COVID testing, maybe having to wear masks, and a few other light restrictions.

column8: Wellness days are terrible. Professors assign more, and more, and more work to "encourage participation" and I work all day everyday, including weekends and wellness days to keep up with the enormous overload of what is essentially busy work. The administration does not seem to have listened to these concerns or adequately directed professors not to do this.
column11: I'd like to see no expense spared to make it fun, with funding for trips, events, a huge graduation, etc. No money has been spent on this sort of thing for nearly two years, so why not make the academic year 2021-2022 as fun and student focused as possible to make up for everything?
column31: Having access to campus spaces is key. Otherwise, what's the point of being on campus?
column32: Longer pass fail deadlines are excellent for managing stress and should be continued. Wellness days are terrible and should be discontinued.
column35: I am on my computer 12-14 hours a day everyday, just to keep up with a normal course load. This is not sustainable and is no way to live, and I feel the administration has not addressed this. This is not "just different" this is much harder for no reason at all.
column38: Paying attention, sitting in one spot all day, looking at a computer is not conducive to learning.
column40: I have seen nearly no one and personally interacted with nearly no one, and the administration sending a conciliatory email with a link to Room13 is no help at all.
column41: Campus spaces need to be open.
column44: If classes continue to be entirely remote, and campus spaces aren't open, I will not enroll. I will be a senior, so why should I subject myself to another awful, restrictive year with no real learning for my final year?
column46: Again, whether or not classes are entirely online and campus spaces are open is key.
column47: I think there a relatively few varsity athletes, and if no season means everyone else can be back on campus, then so be it.
column51: My summer plans (thesis work) are based on whether or not I enroll. If Harvard does not release fall plans by this date, I cannot make an informed decision about my work for the summer.

column9: Be a bit less conservative in gathering restrictions for people in the same pod.
column12: All the pomp and circumstance I'm due.
column35: Being online really does just make learning difficult. I've disengaged so much compared to when I was in in-person courses, and my mental health has plummeted, which makes it even harder to concentrate on academic work. Zoom is also finicky, discussions are more difficult in an online format...it's just not the same and I don't think the same amount of information has sunk in, besides the fact that it's not as pleasant learning online.
column38: See the last short-answer response.
column40: There are no in-person events, no dances, no graduation, no senior week events, no games to go to, no free merchandise or food being given out, the gym is extremely limited, common spaces are closed or only open for a small amount of people (mostly by reservation), and everyone is so stressed and fatigued by the pandemic and Zoom learning that a lot of times people are just too tired to hang out.
column42: I won't be there, but giving away free fitness equipment was a nice gesture and probably one of the more helpful actions Harvard could have taken to make student life better. column135: I live in Leverett, and there were a TON of people doing River Run the night before Housing Day. They were being VERY LOUD AND ROWDY--there was NO WAY that no authority figures in either Leverett, Winthrop, DeWolfe, or Quincy didn't hear these kids, but NOTHING was done about it. There are multiple witnesses (there was even an Instagram livestream by Samyra Miller) that showed that not only were people getting, forgive my French, shit-faced and being super loud when people were trying to sleep (mostly underaged kids, but whatever, this is college), but they were totally flouting COVID-19 safety protocols. No masks, large crowds, etc. I even heard cars honking multiple times because they were wandering around in the street, which is just a safety hazard for all parties involved. I am extremely disappointed and absolutely furious that we get reprimanded for innocently, with everything that's going on, forgetting to do Crimson Clear one day, but absolutely NO ONE tried to prevent or break up that disgraceful River Run, or even send out a communication the next day saying that it was unacceptable behavior and wouldn't be tolerated. It was extremely hypocritical of all Harvard authority figures (tutors, resident deans, COMMUNITY HEALTH LEADS) not to do anything about what could very well have been (or possibly is, the incubation period is far from over) a superspreader event right on campus between at least four different residences.
column137: Living at home was physically and mentally unhealthy for me. I was desperate to get back on campus and away from my parents.
column138: Be a bit less strict for people in the same pod and in opening more common areas.
column140: Having authority figures follow through on their jobs, see above rant.
column141: Think carefully about requiring the vaccine for all undergraduates, as some people may have legitimate objections to getting a vaccine that while until now has seemed to be effective, has not had its long-term effects studied. Just think about how many people need to be vaccinated for herd immunity, what the ramifications of requiring or not requiring the vaccine for students would be on everyone on campus.
column165: I know that it was a rant, but I STRONGLY urge you to take seriously this River Run incident. I think it was extremely unacceptable, and the lack of action on the part of authority figures honestly disgusts and profoundly disappoints me.

column8: I have remained engaged with the Harvard social and academic communities, though not to the fullest extent that I would have preferred. Some opportunities have existed for me to interact and remain a fulfilled member of the community.
column9: Increased clarity regarding who exactly was allowed on campus would have been appreciated, as information shared with the student body made it seem that only Seniors and Juniors were allowed on campus, while many other students from other classes without reasons necessitating they were on campus were given permission to be on.
column14: In sharing the necessary information for learning, I think that online learning has done just fine. But in facilitating growing one's network and showing how difficult coursework will be in the future, online learning has not been as successful. I am prepared to declare a concentration in the Fall, but that is nothing of Harvard's doing -- all my own. I would have hoped that Harvard could have done more to share information regarding concentrations and making their experiences more interactive. In returning to an in-person model, I could use more assistance in the world of balancing actually "going" to class (and the time that takes up) plus expectations for in-classroom behavior and interactions.
column15:
The experience of blocking was rather ok for me, nothing out of the ordinary compared to what I heard from previous students. 

A suggestion: to make it so that students are not secluded up and away in the Quad, could it possibly become SOLELY sophomore housing, and juniors and seniors housed by the river?
column31: I would like for a basically normal on-campus experience, with the only restrictions being on large lecture courses (50 or 100+ students) and only limits on extremely large gatherings.
column32: Ability for online office hours with advisors and professors is very nice, and a welcome thing to do when you have a quick question or need assistance. Also, having more take out options in dining halls would be appreciated.
column44: On-campus housing eligibility.
column46: Social interaction!! Wanting to see other people!!

This inequity should be fixed so that ALL students get to interact with others.

column8: I read an article about Cornell and how they were able to reopen their schools for both semesters. The president was talking about how they felt responsible for not only what happened when students were on campus, but also the challenges and spread of COVID when they were online. It made me think about how Harvard sees their students as a liability and doesn't really care.

column8: While classes have done a great job at transitioning to an online platform over the last year, the extracurricular and residential components of Harvard that bolster the campus experience have been less effective online. I feel as though an online semester has been necessary, but at the same time there could have been more to foster more engaging  campus events.
column9: More opportunities for Sophomores given that we have not been able to come back to campus for the most part.
column13: A housing-day type event that combines the festivities that we missed out on with the orientation and integration into the housing system.
column31: Very clear instructions on limitations to socializing while also creating opportunities to have as normal a campus experience as possible. In an ideal world, I would love to see Harvard do what it can to have vaccines available to any student that had not received vaccine prior to Sept. 2021 to allow for normalcy on campus.
column35: The ability to continue to learn in classes, despite the not optimal online format.
column38: Longer Zoom classes are draining, and I feel that there is no separation from classes and work outside of class. I end up spending 16+ hours a day on a screen, including socializing with friends online which I don't think is mentally or physically healthy.
column40: I miss bumping into people casually and not having to schedule online calls or visits with people. Causal interactions are strained when they need to be scheduled, and people have become more removed as they remain stuck with their housemates or living situations, which feels isolating beyond immediate friend groups. Meeting new people during a pivotal time in college has become nearly impossible outside of classes and clubs, which is a major component of Harvard that is lost in an online environment.
column41: There should be more informal opportunities to meet people, rather than a structured event that retracts from simply talking to more people beyond an immediate friendship bubble. I also think that a Virtual Dining Hall could be interesting, where you join a congregate or zoom and hang out with people informally, sort of how individual houses have a community dinner once a week.

column8:
Wellness days have not served their purpose of helping students be well. School-related meetings and responsibilities as well as those from outside of Harvard have permeated these days and rendered them just another weekday. Weekends have also felt less restful for similar reasons. 
Continuing pre-pandemic letter grading has been exhausting as a remote student in a different time zone.
column9: Bring back spring break. Increase flexibility in grading schemes/options for students.
column13: Have an extended (1 week or more) sophomore orientation (but for juniors who were away from campus) filled with community building, fun/social, and advising activities. I want to make up for the experiences and opportunities that I lost while being off campus.
column31: Require that all students who live on campus receive the COVID-19 before or upon arrival to campus. Continue testing programs though in a scaled-down form if everyone is vaccinated. column32: Record lectures ‚Äì this has been incredibly helpful in classes where the professor talks fast, skims over topics, or erases drawings quickly so that I can go back and finish my notes or review explanations.
column35: My professors have worked very hard to adapt their classes to a remote format and they've done a decent job. I still feel like I am learning the content well enough, but am still severely missing out on the classroom and lab experiences of class.
column38: It is much more exhausting and much less engaging to sit in front of a computer all day, unable to go outside between classes, than to sit in a classroom with walking breaks in between. Students are much less likely to talk or collaborate in a Zoom classroom than in-person.
column40: It has become much, much harder to meet new people or spontaneously run into friends/friendly acquaintances remotely than in-person, which was one of my favorite parts of living on-campus in a residential community. column41: The residential experience.

column8: Though I'm trying to stay as optimistic as possible, as a FGLI sophomore at the College, I feel very dissatisfied with the Spring 2021 semester and the 2020-2021 school year as a whole. Since sophomores have not been invited back on campus this entire academic year, I have been at home and struggling with motivation, focus, isolation, family issues, and so much more. It has been especially difficult this semester, since it's been over a year now that I have experienced an even semi-normal semester of classes. And with summer and fall plans still unannounced, I am very anxious that I'll be stuck home even longer and miss basically all of my Harvard experience.
column9: Since I was hoping to be on campus this semester, I had to decide against petitioning so that I could get the $5,000 reimbursement to use for my family's needs like bills, groceries, etc. I know many FGLI students (especially the FGLI sophomores) have had to make similar tough decisions deciding between this money from Harvard and having a stable learning environment on campus. I wish Harvard would have not made FGLI students decide between these two, and still fully reimbursed low-income students living on campus.
column13: First, of course, would be bringing us back to campus in Fall of 2021. I think there should be events specifically for sophomores since we really have missed out on a lot this year. Though my house has been really involved via Zoom (go Quincy!!) I definitely don't feel fully a part of the community, and I know most of my sophomore friends still know absolutely nothing about their houses due to the lack of communication and events virtually. So focusing specifically on the sophomore class to make up for this lost time would be really great.
column31: I think Harvard has done an amazing job at testing and taking health precautions to protect those on campus. Continuing their system now would be great, though I'm sure it will be much more intense and difficult with much more people back on campus. If we do get to a state where we can have small gatherings safely, I would love to see Harvard helping organize/fund these small events for community-bonding and much-needed socialization outside of the computer screen. I also think that Harvard should be much more strict on students who break the COVID 19 guidelines and safety rules since I know that was a huge issue in the fall semester and it seemed that nothing happened to those who were jeopardizing the health and housing of those around them.
column32: NEVER CONSIDER CONTINUING WELLNESS DAYS. Professors do not follow them, students are still doing work on those days, and everyone knows it's just a sham. Yes, it is the best thing to do this year to avoid spring break trips, but PLEASE do not even consider continuing them. We need spring break.
column35: Though I still enjoy my classes, it is nowhere near the same as having in-person lectures and actually being able to talk to my professors. I have not been asking questions in classes or going to office hours due to my anxiety and being overwhelmed by Zoom, so it has been much more difficult to clarify concepts and form connections with my professors and fellow classmates.
column38: The lack of motivation, focus, and socialization are really what makes online learning so difficult. My coursework itself has actually gotten a bit less intense online, but it is much harder to complete it to my satisfaction as compared to being in the on-campus environement.
column40: Well, I haven't had a social life this year. The extent of my social life is calling my friends on Zoom once every 1-2 months, and though that's always great, it's nothing like getting every meal together like we used to pre-COVID. Especially since I live at home with just my one parent and do not leave my house due to the pandemic, I always feel very alone and isolated.
column41: Honestly, I think it goes without saying that Harvard cannot fully return to a pre-COVID campus by this Fall. But despite this, I think Harvard needs to prioritize bringing more students back on campus rather than prioritizing in-person/hybrid classes. I think it is much more important to make sure everyone who wants to be on campus can be in the Fall so that we can begin to repair the social decline felt by all students, staff, and professors. Since this is already challenging in terms of maintaining public health and safety, I think having completely virtual classes but everyone being on campus is WAY preferred over having some people back on campus and them having hybrid/in-person classes availible.
column44: I will definitely enroll if myself and my friends are able to live on campus, and I definitely might not enroll if we aren't able to. Since I don't have the money to pay for an apartment off-campus (and the $5,000 reimbursement is definitely not enough), my only options are living at home or on-campus. I don't want to waste another semester of my college career, so I don't want to throw away over half of my Harvard experience by taking classes from my childhood bedroom.

column8: (As I know isn't a unique idea,) the wellness days have been pretty un-well for me. Not only do professors occasionally schedule more work for periods with those days in between, but assignment schedules, more generally, just keep going as usual over those days, and it's been impossible for me not to spend those days working. These aren't built-in rest days if resting on them gets me behind. I could use nothing more than a week of decreased Zoom and decreased tension due to a more flexible schedule, which is exactly what Spring Break (even if it included some work) could be. Unfortunately, I am nearly 8 weeks into a developing Zoom-brain situation with about 8 more weeks to go. I'd also like to mention that classes could probably be doing more to mitigate that screen-time excess. I have not observed any one of my classes--even those with the most sympathetic instructors--trying to combine instruction strategies to keep screen/video time under control. A hybrid synchronous-asynchronous class meeting schedule would, even without a spring break, be an incredibly useful contribution--at least from my perspective--to student wellness.
column9: I'm not sure I know enough about the virus-spread data Harvard was using for that decision to assess whether maybe it should have been different.
column14: I feel fairly ready to choose a concentration this fall, but only because of the interests and goals with which I arrived at Harvard. The only aspect of class rigor about which I'm uncertain, when thinking about adjusting to classes in person, is the assessment/exam component. I do feel that timed assessment circumstances are so altered by the remote situation, that I really have no idea what that will be like in a normal class environment. They may be more difficult, due to ease of access to notes immediately before starting in a remote environment, or they may be easier, since my thinking becomes so much hazier in the midst of a Zoom-class day.
column15: I do not feel that I really know my block-mates. I was friends with one of them while on campus, but not close friends, and I have only met the others a few times over Zoom. Even on campus, as a relatively quiet person, the lack of shared time in classes and extracurricular activities made it very difficult to find close friends, and over Zoom, this is nearly impossible. Zoom meetings are bound to include more "presentation" than in-person experiences, and it is difficult to understand who people genuinely are whom I have mostly or solely spoken with by video.
column31: An opportunity for student music groups to meet in-person, even if some restrictions remain, would be wonderful. Sending in recordings and meshing them together digitally is just not the same...For performer or listener (and certainly does not allow for the same sense of community).
column44: The only case in which I would not enroll would be if my class was not invited back to campus.
column46: I would very much like to experience the on-campus college life in a more normal environment than there was last fall.

column118: The only major adjustment that I think would be incredibly useful is a decreased Zoom-class load. These scheduled synchronous meetings not only burn out my ability to think simply due to all of the video time, but they necessitate sitting in one place for hours at a time, which, at least for me, makes it very difficult to focus (and honestly just makes me feel a bit sick some days). Turning off one's camera is also an awkward transition to make in the middle of a smaller-sized class, even in the cases where professors might permit that.

column8:
This semester (actually this entire school year) has been the worst of my life. I dread waking up in the morning because I know I will be forced to bask in the light of an overpriced Apple product for at least 12 hours every single day. Every hour of every day, since school started in September, has been numbingly consumed with school work, Zoom meetings, and sorting through numerous emails containing unsatisfactory gestures from the university to "increase a sense of community during this virtual year." However, this "virtual year" only applies to sophomores at the College. All other classes were invited back on campus, but the class of 2023 has been completely cast aside by the "best" University in the world, having been barred from any opportunity to return to campus this year. Furthermore, the University refuses to even acknowledge their complete disregard for the Class of 2023. 

When I enrolled at Harvard, I was expecting an experience filled with personal discovery and educational and intellectual exploration. Instead, I have been gifted with 12+ hours on a computer every day and, subsequently, depression and extreme burn-out with no support from the University. As a sophomore, nearly half of my "Harvard experience" will be through the screen of my computer, crammed in the corner of my bedroom. I used to love school; my first semester at Harvard was incredible and I loved every second of it. Now, I dread every single aspect of my "education." It is crushing when I see that my high school friends are able to interact with their peers and continue to have their transformative college experiences while I am stuck at home, counting down the days until this dreadful school year is over. I wish the University would have considered this, and similar experiences, when planning for the spring. 

In order to "make up" for this, the University apparently only sees one acceptable response: to allow those who stayed at home all year to enroll in two Harvard Summer School classes for "free." However, this opportunity is only free if one decides to take theses classes from... Yep, you guessed it! - HOME. With a $40+ billion endowment, this response from the University is utterly embarrassing. Further, these summer courses will also be entirely virtual. I think I can speak for the entire class of 2023 when I say that THE LAST THING any of us want to do is take MORE ONLINE CLASSES. But somehow, the University thinks this is an acceptable way to make up for months of depression, lack of support, no interaction with peers, and countless other detrimental side effects of being cast aside by the "best university in the world." At this point, I think I would have been much better off attending any other school than Harvard. At least then I would still have my drive to learn, my mental stability, and my passion for things I once loved.

column9: They could have done full capacity for on campus students‚ÄîHarvard has the ability to create a bubble of students and provide resources for the campus to social distance properly. Encouraging students to be on campus and thus being able to hold some kind of regulation over all students would cut down on off-campus living around Boston, which had resulted in on-campus students going to large, unsafe parties hosted by off-campus students. Finally, Harvard should have considered some limited in-person class at the willingness of faculty, at least to allow international students to be on campus. From my understanding, an international First-Year student would have been unable to obtain a visa to be in the US whether or not they were in campus if no classes were in person‚Äîbrown university held very few in person classes just so international students could be on campus. Could Harvard have had a first year international student seminar and made that the only in person class?

column8: Harvard still isn't offering in-person classes, despite allowing students to go into Boston and gather in groups -- two activities that are wildly more dangerous than having classes with limited in-person components. This means that as a first-year international student, I am unable to come to campus and must deal with taking classes at midnight, because Harvard has valued the need of domestic students to be in Boston more than it has our need of a somewhat normal sleep schedule, connection with classmates, and education in daylight hours. In addition, many peer institutions ARE allowing international students on campus, and Harvard has never given us a satisfactory reply to why they are not.

column42: As a rising senior, I am hoping so badly that things can be as normal as possible. Although I certainly understand the need to be extra cautious at the beginning of the pandemic, I think that Harvard has been much more conservative than most other colleges in terms of freedoms granted to their students and they should give more freedom and trust to their students to act responsibly, especially considering the fact that the vaccine is out now and will likely be offered to anyone who wants it before the start of the fall semester.
column46: I prefer to live on-campus in Quincy House with my block mates, but if I feel there are too many restrictions on campus, then I feel as might as well live at home in southern Virginia where the only non-normal thing going on right now is mask-wearing in businesses/restaurants. For example, I can travel when and where I want to, I can play sports with friends without wearing masks, I can visit friends' houses, etc.
column47: I think Harvard should definitely allow Fall sports to the fullest extent possible. It was a shame that all other 31 Division 1 college basketball conferences could hold competitive seasons for their students, but the Ivy League felt it could not. Furthermore, then the Ivy League cancelled Spring sports for the second time. If middle and high school students in my small "redneck" hometown can play organized fall, winter, and spring sports responsibly, then I have no idea why college (Ivy League!) athletes can't be trusted to do the shame. I have been very understanding of Harvard's rules, regulations, and decisions regarding academic instruction and know that although it is not ideal, they are doing the very best they can. On the athletic side, however, I must say I have been very ashamed of the Ivy League/Harvard's response in terms of athletic events and feel terrible for our athletes.
column51: Personally, as long as I have a three week window before classes start, that will be plenty of time to make a decision and prepare. column52: Nothing I can think of! I would just note that I think Harvard should be as less restrictive as possible and trust its students to do the right thing and follow minimal rules. However, I think having strict punishments for breaking these minimal restrictions would be just.
column115: Coming from someone on financial aid, I think Harvard's financial aid policy is extremely generous and I am very grateful for it. Thank y'all so much for your generous support!

column8: I definitely feel disappointed by Harvard's Spring 21 semester, as I feel like we are at a point where pretty much every professor feels like we should be "used to" the situation by now, and are not as empathetic as they were. Similarly, every communication I get from the College feels like a bad motivational poster with no action to actually support students.
column9: I honestly think Harvard's physical reopening plan has been pretty good and one of the better ones I've seen with the regards to Covid safety. However, I don't think there have been enough strides made to address inequality in people's conditions for the year, and there was never really a plan to address those in the first place. While I do understand the logic behind Wellness Days and their placement throughout the semester, they have been completely disappointing and I haven't had one that has felt like a true day off the entire semester, and I feel no support from the College in making sure that doesn't happen. I basically feel like everything about Wellness Days reads as "yeah, we know you hate them and usually have even more work to do on them, but we won't actually do anything about it," which is very disheartening.
column13: I personally feel almost no affiliation to the house to which I was assigned, so I guess coming back and having events specifically for sophomores to get to know the house and staff would be good.
column31: I would definitely need to see equity in who is invited back to campus and what privileges are granted to those who are living on campus. For example, if athletes are allowed to resume practices and competitions as they were before the pandemic, it would be unfair to enforce restrictions on other extracurricular activities. Furthermore, it would be important for Harvard to genuinely enforce social distancing and COVID-19 restrictions, including keeping space in classrooms and continuing to pay maintenance and custodial staff (!!!) to keep spaces clean between class meetings. I would like access to libraries and other facilities, even if they are restricted.
column32: I absolutely cannot do another year of Wellness Days; they have compounded my stress rather than alleviating it. I do not know how ending the semester early would be beneficial to anyone IF public health guidance allows travel, etc. Of course, if the situation is still bad enough that it would be unsafe to have students travel off-campus for Thanksgiving and return, I understand an early move-out date, but I still would not want to have exams before Thanksgiving, as that would rush the semester too much.
column35: Remote classes limit what I actually learn, Zoom fatigue contributes to a lack of desire to attend events outside of classes (including office hours as well as events hosted by clubs), and Harvard's expectation that we've had ample time to adjust and thus should be able to keep up with the same academic rigor as we would on campus (and some professors creating even more work to make sure that we are keeping on track).
column40: I live off-campus and have roommates who are Harvard students as well, which is nice, but I truly have not interacted with other peers in so long. I miss being able to just sit in d-halls and libraries and talk to people, and I don't think any Zoom events can really match that experience unfortunately.
column41: If Harvard cannot return to full pre-COVID campus life in the Fall, I would almost certainly take time off, as I don't think remote learning is engaging or sustainable, and I do not feel prioritized in any way by the College.
column44: If learning is remote again (even if students are allowed on campus), I will likely take time off.
column46: I haven't yet lived in my assigned house, so I'd really like the chance.

All in all, online is very detrimental to our learning and mental wellbeing.

column8: Most of my friends at other colleges have been hybrid all year, and their campuses have experienced minimal coronavirus outbreaks. Meanwhile, we were given the unenviable choice of living in the dorms, with quite restrictive conditions (there was no timetable given for the opening that has occurred), or staying home, or spending a substantial amount of money on on-campus housing. I would have much preferred being on campus with lighter restrictions.
column9: Hybrid classes and lighter housing restrictions.

I'm moving toward a degree, but I'm not improving as a person or deepening any friendships.

column38: They're challenging in different ways. Online learning is easier because there are fewer distractions to use up your time, but if I wanted to cloister myself, I could do that just as easily on campus.

column8: Harvard has provided poor mental health services during this time. For those of us who have already met with a CAMHS therapist in the past, we were not allowed to meet with one again unless it's urgent care. I find this to be quite a terrible policy, as it fails to acknowledge that many of us with chronic mental health issues have only gotten worse/had our illnesses reemerge, needing treatment again, due to the COVID-19  pandemic.
column9: I would have allowed many more students on campus and allowed a greater degree of community. I think students must be allowed to eat in dining halls again soon and be allowed to have guests in their rooms. I think Harvard has to consider the mental health cost of isolation on campus. The reason why I did not return to campus is because of the severely limited social interactions allowed in some phases and the inadequate amount of mental health resources for students dealing with this isolation. Harvard fails to acknowledge the significant damage the isolation students suffer when essentially confined to their rooms.
column11: Permission to allow greater social interactions between students, as well as hybrid classes. column8: I don't think there's any way really for me to be satisfied with a virtual semester. I'm of the opinion that wellness days have accomplished nothing: I've had multiple classes simply reschedule the lesson plans for the day to an extra non-class hour, and the work builds up anyways where the lack of an extended period of time without classes means that I (and many of my friends who I've talked to) are experiencing this semester with no breaks. That is difficult in a normal year, and with the added pressures of a global pandemic, it makes things incredibly difficult on mental wellbeing. On the bright side, I've actually enjoyed my classes a lot this semester. I think professors have adapted pretty well to Zoom and most are very understanding given the circumstances.
column9: I understand the college wanting students to not travel, but I would have allowed for some extended break- even if that meant putting a couple wellness days in a row during the week or planning the Monday/Friday one to ensure a four-day weekend.
column13: I honestly don't know. The House will be busy welcoming the new class of sophomores into the community, and I don't want to intrude on those events.
column31: I believe that if Harvard can ensure that all returning students, faculty, and workers are vaccinated, the students should be allowed to socialize as they normally would. We could maybe create a literal "Harvard bubble" of covid safety. I think it's absolutely possible for everyone to be invited back, and I really really hope Harvard does all it can to make that a reality.
column32: Definitely no wellness days moving forward. Allowing people to attend big lectures online would be a positive I think, but I'd also like to have the option to go in-person.
column35: I have moved into upper-level classes so I think it's wholly reliant on me taking classes that are of greater interest to me. In terms of the actual environment, though, I think seminars/smaller classes suffer greatly from this format, and community building in those classes is very difficult on Zoom.
column38: It is much more exhausting and I feel burnt-out.
column40: I miss interacting with people in person. I have stayed close with many friends, but the spontaneous interactions have completely disappeared, and there are people I will never see again who I might not have formed lasting relationships with, but who I enjoyed the company of.
column41: Social life. I can't imagine the detriment to our development/mental health if we are unable to fully interact with our peers for two full years, especially in our late teens/early twenties.
column42: Acknowledgment that this past year has been awful. I know they're trying their best, but I want the administration to stop saying that this is "different, not worse" or whatever phrase they've used. We can simultaneously realize that independent growth has occurred and that this past year has been stolen from all of us. It sucks, and I want them to stop pretending like it hasn't.
column46: I want to be close to my friends and be able to feel like I'm fully part of my House community.

column8:
The time zone difference and lack of opportunities for international students is still awful. Because there are no casual hallway conversations on Zoom, I still don't know many fellow students and Harvard and the ones I do know are people I talk to for 30 seconds a week in class if that. 

All that being said, I do like using a computer for my studies as it makes it easier for looking up content during class/lecture when I am unsure of a topic or a keyword that is being used. I have gotten so used to online learning that I fear going to Harvard campus/lectures for the first time will be a scary experience. 

If I look at Harvard to be a learning experience, I would say it's going amazingly well, but when I consider Harvard to be a life experience, this way of living is very depressing and I am desperate to actually visit the campus I'm meant to call my second home.
column9: Fight for the international freshman more. It is gut wrenching to see other international frosh at other colleges be supported so that they can get a visa and live on campus while we have to imagine what it could be like once we get there.
column14: As I have said above, I have enjoyed online learning as it has fitted my way of learning well. I am unsure whether I'll be suited to in-person classes when things go back to normal which unnerves me. I am ready to choose a concentration however that is only because I am a UK student that already had to decide what I wanted to study when I was 16 (due to the UK uni system) and I feel like its only through my previous choices that I know what I want to do. I want to know how long in-person lectures will be, because if I struggle to keep focus for 75 mins, I don't know how I will survive 2+ hours.
column15: I have made no close friends that are fellow first years so in some ways, the blocking process was very easy for me. I was expected to choose people that I would live with for the next 3 years when I haven't even met anyone in real life! I'm sorry but that is insane! I ended up blocking as a single because I was not confident in choosing, let alone asking people who barely know me (especially when they have lived on campus with many other students in the fall semester). If first years still have to choose blocking groups in covid times, I suggest that they either make it random or delay the process until everyone is on campus because it was too much to ask of us.

column8: As a freshman, I decided to stay at home for the spring semester. This was a good decision for my own health and for my family's health. It's really allowed me to focus a bit more on my wellness, and together as a family, it has really given us a lot of time to enjoy each other's company. However, the time zone difference made a lot of communications with the school (professors, advisors, etc.) much more difficult, so there were times when I felt lonely and a bit helpless. I have tried to attend more online social events, but sometimes, I refuse to attend these meetings because it's contributing greatly to my daily screen time (which can sometimes spike up to 12 hours). As a result of this, I sometimes suffer from eye strain, fatigue, and burn out. I know this is not ideal for anyone, but I understand that everyone is going through their own struggles, so I have really been appreciating all the kind words that the administration team has sent out to undergraduates.
column9: First of all, I would have really appreciated if Harvard announced their Spring plan earlier. The plan announcement time was really inconvenient for many of us who need to plan their trip, tickets, and all things that come with traveling. Second, it would have been EXTREMELY helpful if Spring Break still took place. Right now, I am feeling like I am always doing work, even on Wellness Days, which sort of defeats the purpose of Wellness Days. I am always on my screen, working on endless assignments, submitting endless projects and essays. There's really not a time for me to rejuvenate because I am always anxious about work and missing deadlines (especially with the online format, keeping track of dates becomes even harder). I have been feeling burnt out since the end of February, and all that's holding me together so far is the countdown until summer break.
column14: Online learning has definitely given me a taste of the rigors of Harvard's academics. I wouldn't say I am confident with the academics here because I think there's a huge part of the classroom experience that is lacking in my academic journey. However, I do have to acknowledge that some of my professors have really tried their best to make things interesting even with the Zoom format and to lighten up the Zoom room every once in a while.

column32: This COVID-era Harvard has presented to me an immense of flexibility that the school has. I hope to continue to see this flexibility in the future.

column8: As someone who is not on campus, my experiences this semester have largely been rather banal and uninteresting. Classes have definitely improved in their execution of online teaching, but it still lacks the charm and strengths of in-person learning.
column9: Honestly, I would have been more hesitant to open up than was the University this semester. I have heard that case rates on campus are low and therefore the administration is not as worried about policies such as allowing guests in one's rooms, but the massive increase in total area cases relative to last semester would make me, at the very least, more worried about letting so many people back on campus.
column14: Given that I do not have a basis with which to compare typical Harvard academic rigor with that of the COVID-era, I cannot adequately respond to the first question. I do feel my academics are very sound, and I am not particularly concerned with how they will fare going into future semesters. I have had an idea of what my concentration would be from long before I entered college and, as such, I believe myself to be ready to choose one in the fall. I think, in regard to teaching in an in-person learning model, it would definitely be helpful for the University to provide us with directions and perhaps some leniency in arriving late to class, as I have little to no idea where the actual academic buildings on campus are.
column15: The blocking process was rather smooth and easy, with the website being intuitive and easy to access. I think the only issue with the blocking process this semester was the inherent difficulty that comes with finding block mates in the era of COVID. I do not think significant changes will need to be made in this regard, as this problem should hopefully just be one of my class.
column31: I would like to see vaccine mandates and subsequent intervention by the University in favor of getting its students, faculty, and staff the vaccine. I would also like to see the guest policy from this semester return, as well as the potential for renting out indoor spaces, like common rooms, assuming that they are still unavailable to students. As someone who lived on campus in the fall, I found the measures that we had in place then to be so restrictive and grating that it had negative effects on my academic performance, so I would like to see next semester's model resemble this current semester's design, though even more open.

column14: I don't think I have been effectively acclimated to the rigors of Harvard academics. Many of my professors have been very aware of the impact of the pandemic on our capacity to work, so they have been more lenient. This was a good decision on their part, but I think it will leave me feeling very overwhelmed when I have to take Harvard courses during a normal year. I have only had 1 closed-book exam, deadlines have been very flexible, and the workload has been lighter than usual, so I think I am in for a shock in the upcoming years and don't feel too confident with my academics. I don't feel entirely ready to choose a concentration in the fall, but that has less to do with online learning and more to do with my interest in a variety of topics. I think tips on time management (especially with having to commute to classes for the first time), stress management, and office hours would be helpful resources.
column15: I was not prepared for the blocking process at all. The administration said they understood that the pandemic put stress on the process, but they did nothing to alleviate this. Blocking strained the very few friendships I was able to make under the circumstances we are in, and the deadline was the same as it was in previous years despite us having far less time and capacity to socialize and build relationships. I honestly think the blocking process causes unnecessary conflict and would advocate for individuals to get assigned houses rather than entire groups. Either that or allowing larger groups to block together so things are less exclusionary.

column9: I wish Harvard would have brought more students back, but I also don't know if they could have made that decision safely. column14: I think online learning has been fairly representative of Harvard academic rigor, but given that I have nothing to compare it to, I honestly don't know. column8: I find that my spring semester has been reasonably enjoyable only as a result of the fact that I love the subject matter of my classes. I do not believe that this semester is itself an improvement over the fall‚Äîor, indeed, the previous spring. I still believe that social isolation is quite prevalent, and Harvard-sponsored events have done little to change this.
column9: Although I do not think the Spring 2021 semester has been particularly good in and of itself, I do not know what I would have done differently from the administration.
column13: I don't think much can be done to help sophomores integrate more effectively to their House. At least in my case, I know I avoid things like house events because I do not enjoy them. I have found that the only way for me to effectively integrate with a given community has been simply to spend a lot of time within that community. I don't believe this time can be made up with special events or accommodations to the current sophomore class when they return to campus.
column31: I would like to see a requirement that all students that come on-campus be verifiably vaccinated (ideally, not relying on student self-reporting), with vaccines provided by HUHS at no cost to the student.
column32: I greatly appreciate the general move to electronic submission of assignments, and I would like to see it continue. I would also like to see the continued use of masks for students who are sick, though I imagine this is more likely only going to happen with a certain amount of cultural change.
column35: I believe that virtual education is almost inherently worse than an in-person one. This is for several reasons, ranging from the ease with which students can become distracted to mental health concerns and social isolation, to a decrease in the amount of interaction within classes, but I do not believe that these problems can be addressed while remaining in a virtual environment.
column40: As with virtual learning, I believe that virtual socialization is inherently less valuable than in-person socialization. This may of course be addressed by e.g. students living off-campus with friends, but this creates a financial incentive to stay home, ultimately leading to significant social isolation.
column41: The most important part of in-person life was being able to talk to and spend time with friends. I believe this particular part could be adapted to be more safe by requiring students to e.g. form pods. I also believe that on-campus research should be taken as a valid reason to request on-campus housing.
column46: Ultimately, I am interested in on-campus housing because I believe it is the best way for me to avoid the social isolation I have experienced over the past year.
column113: I have deliberately chosen my schedule in such a way that would effectively maximize the amount of time I spend working, either on problem sets or on one of my three part-time jobs.

This may, however, be a product of the financial aid system, as I am not receiving financial aid and am instead taking out loans for the cost of college.

column8: So far, I am enjoying my classes this semester. In terms of academics, things are going well. However, I still feel the pressure of not having any meaningful relationships with other students. I look forward to hopefully making friends on campus in Fall 2021, but I must admit that I am disappointed in the fact that I couldn't block with people who I consider my "friends" because I do not have any. I understand that the COVID-19 pandemic has brought unprecedented circumstances, but it is still difficult realizing that almost 1/4 of my Harvard career is now behind me and I feel like I have not really experienced anything yet.
column9: I think Harvard's Spring 2021 plan was an appropriate improvement from the fall. The University seems to be doing what it can to function through this public health crisis.
column14: Since my only experience with Harvard academics is virtual, I really do not have anything to compare it to. But, with that being said, I have enjoyed most of my classes this year and the academic rigor has been manageable thus far. I feel pretty confident with my academics, but I worry that the rigor of virtual learning may understate the conventional difficulty level of Harvard academics.
column15: I am really disappointed about how blocking went. Housing Day was one of the biggest things that drew me to Harvard when I first considered applying. I do not want to place the blame for the disappointment that I feel on anyone in particular, but I would be lying if I said I was pleased. I had hoped to enter the housing lottery with a blocking group of friends, but instead I hardly knew enough people to make a group at all. The lottery itself, though, was just like any other year I assume and I am happy with the house I was placed in. In the future, there should be more socially rich opportunities to engage with classmates as early as Visitas, with a specific emphasis on building relationships and thinking about blocking.
column31: If some combination of in-person, hybrid, and remote learning is necessary then I think it is very important that the course setting is thoughtfully considered. In my opinion, large introductory courses such as the Ec10 series would be better delivered remotely. On the other hand, seminars and Expos Studio classes would be better delivered in-person. Ultimately, I would hate to see certain classes offered in-person over other classes if the format of those classes does not necessitate or even benefit from being in-person.
column32: Something tells me that large introductory classes like the Ec10 series are better delivered online as opposed to in a large lecture hall. On Zoom, all 500+ students have an up-close view of the teaching staff and lecture notes. Each student probably benefits from sitting at their own desk to take notes during these types of classes, as opposed to trying to take notes in cramped lecture hall seating. I wouldn't mind continuing the online format of these large lectures, but then still offering office hours and Sections in-person.
column46: I am eager to make friends and experience upperclassmen house life. I am also hoping to attend seminars, sections, and office hours in-person.
column47: I think varsity sports should be held in Fall 2021 with the appropriate safety precautions. This means that athletes, coaches, student athletic trainers, student managers, etc. should all be invited back to games and practices.
column48: Harvard should continue to waive the student summer work expectation and term-time work expectation at least until Summer 2022. I feel very strongly about this as do many of my classmates with whom I have spoken to. If there is one response in this entire survey that should be given the MOST weight, let it be this one.
column51: As much as I would appreciate an early decision, I want Harvard to base its Fall 2021 plans on the most accurate expectations of what life will be like in the fall. We could se drastic changes in the public health situation within the short time between April 2021 and June 2021.
