column8: I am an international freshman who has been studying remotely for the entire year. I have an 11 hour time difference (but currently 10 hours since daylight savings have resumed) which has been detrimental to my health owing to severe lack of sleep and a chaotic (and almost non-existent) schedule amidst a workload that would be ordinarily hard under normal conditions to begin with. I haven't been able to participate in much of the opportunities on offer (extracurricular or otherwise), and the handful I did manage to take (e.g. Harvard i-Labs) have sessions at ungodly hours in my time zone, making it more difficult for me to utilise such opportunities since they also do not record a majority of their events for internationals like myself to watch. Furthermore, though there are a few people of my nationality/place of origin who are undergraduates at the college, I am the only one from my country who is not a US resident and hence its harder (understandably) for my peers to empathize with my situation, not that the utter lack of socialization for me (owing to my current place of residence) is a primary concern of mine right now.
column9: Recording ALL academic and extracurricular sessions and remove all need (at least for people a certain number of hours ahead/behind of EST) to attend synchronous sessions, so that we too are able to access the resources/opportunities Harvard has on offer without sacrificing essential needs such as sleep. Furthermore, despite scheduling problems, I would have not gotten rid of spring break; wellness days in the middle of the week mean nothing if people still end up having to work on those days due to upcoming assignments/assessments due on (or around) that day.
column14: I think with 4 hours of sleep a day during the week with little to no consideration for people's schedules through putting up office hours or help sessions at wonky hours of day, with little social interaction and sometimes even a lack of resources, online learning has successfully emulated the authentic experience of a college student going through the rigorous academic process of Harvard. Surprising as this sounds, and by that I refer to making resources accessible; no use doing all these otherwise valuable and engaging events if I can't access them owing to no recordings being available for me to watch later. For the rest, can't do much myself if an institution like Harvard with all that it has can't resolve these issues even after a whole year online. I feel rather let-down by my ability to keep up with all this but nothing much I can do or say will change the past. I was entirely ready with a concentration choice coming into Harvard since they work well with my future plans (if those ever work out that is).
column15: I couldn't care less about the blocking process, frankly because I am sort of accustomed to the process of being assigned boarding houses from previous schooling (interestingly enough). Though I wish for the sake of my peers that a more sociable and interactive atmosphere around blocking is fostered. column8:
Being able to have visitors in my room is an amazing adjustment. The housing day activities were somewhat lacking and relatively boring, but I appreciate support from the numerous councils and clubs at Harvard that have sent along merch and stuff to make us feel somewhat connected. 

I appreciate that more of the facilities are open, and there are more opportunities to get out of the house. It's incredibly challenging working from home or from your dorm, and just having an excuse to study or sit in a Zoom lecture anywhere but your dorm brightens your mood exponentially.

The food, now that it's hot and the caf is getting the swing of things, is significantly better, albeit still sucky, than last semester.
column9: I think I'm happy with it. I'm always confused by the whole "other people can't sleep in your dorm" policy, though. Why is that a thing?
column14: I feel relatively confident to face the rigors of Harvard academics. I'm very ready to choose my concentration. I think what would be most helpful is knowing what strategies people use to organize their time once they have to get up and actually go to class... also being well-informed on all of the different study spaces there are would be helpful.
column15: Nothing! I thought it was great. I'm only a bit worried that I won't actually have my blocking group as my suitemates. I wouldn't choose gender inclusive housing unless I was guaranteed to have my blocking group as suitemates, since there are two cisgender men in my blocking group. As someone afab and nonbinary, it's very risky for me to opt into gender inclusive housing, so I would only feel comfortable doing it if I had the guarantee that the only people I'm sharing a common room/bathroom/general living space with were my blocking folks.
column31:
No hybrid classes. Either in-person or not. Hybrid classes (I've been in a few in HS) are SO SO hard to manage for online students joining in synchronously. 

No wellness days. Please. I can't stand them. I really genuinely just need a week to sleep and establish a healthy life routine, and one day in the middle of the week is only enough to catch up on work. It's horrible. 

Please no more move-outs. I'd love it if we could try to guarantee year-long housing. I moved out before Thanksgiving, which was very strenuous on me and my injured father, and then I moved in for Spring, and then they switched my dorm last minute so I moved out and moved in again. It's so horrible.
column32: Recorded lectures. I love that lectures are recorded and you can look back on them.
column46: Lacking conditions for learning at home
column52: Outdoor heating, just in case COVID policies are still a thing. It's so chilly out.

column8: I'm simply exhausted with the workload and lack of time available to have a significant rest. The wellness days interspersed through the semester simply do not give the reprieve necessary in order to stay mentally and emotionally health. This is especially obvious when the lack of class doesn't correlate to a lack of deadlines and assignments, or even the deadlines being pushed back a day. It's nearly impossible to actually take an entire day off if I have a paper or project due the next day.
column9: I would have allowed for a spring break. I know that Harvard was really worried about students traveling during this time and potentially being infected, but there were better ways to handle that concern than to simply take away spring break. Spring break is more than a time for students to travel or have fun; more than anything it's a time to take a breathe without having assignment constantly looming over your head. I would have suggested either that on campus residences are required to stay in residence for the duration of spring break with the same rules we have now, or that students who stayed overnight anywhere would have to go through arrival quarantine again.
column14: I feel sufficiently introduced to the rigors or Harvard academics, but I can't say I feel well equipped to handle them. I am personally worried about my ability to maintain my own mental health and wellbeing while still performing well in class, and I don't feel very confident in my academic at Harvard. I simply feel as though I'm not performing at the level I need to be. In regards to deciding my concentration, I have a really clear idea that I want to study two fields although I don't know the specifics of how I would structure my studies (a joint concentration vs having a major/minor, and which will be my focus)
column15: I felt really distanced from people and that I didn't have anyone to block with really. Although I know a decent percentage of students enter the lottery alone, it still is kind of a hit to the gut that I didn't have any friends who wanted to block with me. If I could make any changes, I think it would be nice to have a system (sort of like data match maybe) to help people who don't have a blocking group find one if they'd like to. Or a system where students can write in a list of other freshman they'd like to block with and if two students both write in each others names their notified about it.
column31: I would like for the semester to start earlier into the fall, maybe mid to late August instead of first week of September, and use the extra time to give students wellness days through out the semester in addition to a normal Thanksgiving and winter recess. In terms of classes, with Harvard having such a rapid testing policy for on campus students in-person classes are much more doable. I would like to see a hybrid of in-person and online classes. Large lectures would remain online, but smaller courses and sections would be in-person with a recording available for online students. I also think the reopening plan for Spring 2021 in regards to common spaces would still be an appropriate measure.
column32: I appreciate wellness days, but only in addition to a normal spring break.
column46: My only other option would be to learn remotely from home and that wouldn't be a good learning environment. Also, while having online classes takes a lot away from the college experience, being physically on campus makes it better.
column48: I think Harvard should continue to give students on financial aid the $3500 in place of their work study and I also think Harvard should provide students facing significant financial challenges the $5000 given to remote students regardless of whether the student is remote or not. I know too many students who were faced with the decision of prioritizing their education and moving to campus for the better learning environment, or staying home in a bad learning environment because of pressure to accept the $5000. It's a terrible position to put a student in where they're forced to make a choice like that because their family is struggling.
column115: The $5000 covid-19 allowance made it really difficult for me to make the decision to return to campus knowing that my family could have really used the extra funds. I eventually came to the decision to return to campus anyway, but that was because of personal issues at home. If my home environment was better, I probably would have stayed.

column8: The lack of a Spring Break has made the semester very difficult. Also, just  not being on-campus has been incredibly difficult ‚Äì both emotionally and from a mental health perspective. Harvard really needs to bring all its students back to campus in the fall.
column9: Bring more classes back to campus and have the on-campus precautions be less strict so that more people would actually come back to campus. Harvard would have been able to manage the Covid-19 threat with regular, three times per week testing while also not restricting Harvard student's movement, interaction, and usage of Harvard spaces that much (because you're testing people all the time so they'd find and isolate any cases before they turn into an outbreak).
column11:
A completely, 100% back-to-normal Fall. There is absolutely no reason why this shouldn't be possible. The vast majority of people will be vaccinated by the start of school in late August, and the U.S will reach herd immunity then or soon after by the vast majority of all estimates. There is no excuse for the Fall 2021 semester to not be entirely in-person, with all grades on campus and all/most classes being in-person. I have spoken to so many people in my class about this, and there is no one that doesn't agree with this! Also, I would really hope that freshman pre-orientation programs (such as FIP) are in-person as well. It is impossible to overstate how important FIP is for incoming international students ‚Äì¬†they have already suffered too much because of not being properly integrated into Harvard, and not allowing future international students to be fully integrated into Harvard and the U.S by not having an in-person FIP would be extremely disappointing. 

Overall, Harvard needs to be planning for an entirely in-person and functionally back-to-normal semester in the fall! There is no reason why a university with the amount of resources that Harvard has couldn't make that happen.
column31: I would like to see as little Covid-19 restrictions as possible, especially since most if not all Harvard students will be vaccinated by then. In any case, I would hope there wouldn't be any restrictions on movement, gathering, interaction, or usage of Harvard spaces. I understand if Harvard wouldn't want to organize any huge international conferences that brings high school students from all over the world, for example, but beyond that I see no reason for why any other restrictions should be in place. I would 100% make sure that Harvard focuses on vaccinating any students who come back to campus and haven't been vaccinated yet (and come up with a plan for them to vaccinate them before school starts, i.e make them arrive early to get the shot so that they can be more or less immune around when school starts or something like that), so that close to 100% of the Harvard population could be vaccinated by the time school starts and the Fall semester could be entirely normal.
column32: Maybe keeping Zoom office hours as an option since those are helpful for quick question. Also open-notes tests and exams. Otherwise, I would really like to see a return to pre-Covid Harvard as quickly as possible.
column35: The fact that the entire social component of learning at Harvard is gone -¬†no friends, no dining hall conversations, no musical or athletic extracurriculars. What you learn in section or lecture is only a tiny fraction of what a Harvard education actually is, and that is the only part that has been preserved this academic year.
column38: Online learning is SO much more challenging! The toll it takes on your mental health, the lack of developing meaningful connections and friendships, and just the general burden of having to spend all day sitting in a chair and staring at a screen for over a year are all unbearable. Harvard has to return to a completely in-person semester in the Fall.
column40: It is literally impossible to meet new people (one of the most exciting parts of going to Harvard); and staying in touch with previous friends is very hard since regularly staying in touch is difficult, people are in different time zones, and Zoom calls cannot replace in person memories being made. There is absolutely no replacement (nothing even comes close) to regular, in-person living with your friends and that is the only way that Harvard can ensure that students have even a somewhat satisfactory social experience in the Fall.
column41: Although Harvard not returning to full pre-Covid campus in the Fall would be the greatest disappointment in the world (and frankly, would just be inexplicable) they should definitely prioritize making sure that all students can get back to campus and creating a situation where all students actually decide to live on campus (as opposed to on-campus). They can do as much testing as they want, but brining 95% of all four years back into the Harvard dorms in the fall is a MUST.
column42: If anyone from the Harvard administration ever reads this message: Please, please please ‚Äì¬†for the sake of the physical and mental health of all Harvard students, please do everything you can to have the Fall semester be as normal as possible and to have all Harvard students back in the dorms as it was before. Remote learning and being away from friends and campus has been so inexplicably detrimental to the physical, mental, emotional, and financial health of me and all of my friends. The only way to alleviate that is to make sure that all students return to campus in the Fall (or 95% of all students, essentially, pre-pandemic levels) so that students can continue their academic and social development and hopefully try to recuperate as much of the last lost year as possible.
column44: Whether or not Harvard will return to a "back to normal" situation in the fall (i.e 95% of all undergraduate students in dorms, no severe restrictions on movement, interaction, and usage of Harvard spaces).
column46: I would live in on-campus housing if everything is back to normal. If Harvard is not back to normal (or very very close to back to normal I would strongly consider taking time off)
column47: I see no reason why they shouldn't be able to continue.

column51: We need to give them enough time to realize that a fully-functional, normal Fall is possible based on high vaccination rates and how quickly herd immunity is approaching.
column52: The most important thing is bringing everyone back to campus. That means 95% of all students living in Harvard dorms as before Covid. That is the only way to avoid the significant toll this remote learning experience has had on students physical, mental, emotional and financial health.

column8: I am feeling really burned out because we don't have spring break. I have really enjoyed my time on campus, though and my professors have been understanding for the most part, so overall, I am happy I enrolled, but have a lot of grievances listed below that really affected my mental health and financial stability.
column9: Added a spring break! Encouraging faculty to respect wellness days (as in, not just moving meetings to a different day). Easier to access mental health services. I liked early shopping week, but faculty should have waited until the first day of school to expect work. I heard some students had to turn in psets within the first two days of class, expected to have watched a lecture or two during shopping week. And above all else, I and many other FGLI students had a tough time choosing between staying home and moving on campus since our funding grant for COVID was only given if we stayed off campus. Students should NOT have had to make this stuff choice. More aid should have been allocated to FGLI students regardless of where they chose to study.
column11: More funding for FGLI students. More support for seniors making post-grad plans. A commencement (if safe). For professors and admin to be understanding, just as many have been given the pandemic's circumstances. More spaces and events to spend time with friends. A spring break.
column31: Safe social events on campus with small groups, strict covid testing for those not vaccinated, online social events as well
column32: Continue semester extensions by the AdBoard, eliminate co-pays for CAMHS sessions beyond the allotted 8 sessions like this year, encourage extra-curricular meetings online when possible, encourage more technology resources to be used (i.e., more faculty should record and upload their lectures), more generous extension policies should be built in by faculty in their syllabus (I noticed more of this during COVID which was great), Harvard should not eliminate Spring Break (but I do like the idea of having 2-3 Wellness days in the Fall and the Spring permanently)
column35: More understanding professors, online courses somehow give me less anxiety (office hours are easier, I can take a 15min breather in between, I can watch recorded lectures again), professors have made an effort to build community with us in my courses, I love that I can attend a ton more events on Zoom (like talks, social events, etc.) and I don't feel like they're of less quality than in-person ones
column36: Online learning and in-person learning are equally challenging
column38: I really thrived when I could spend evenings and nights at Lamont because I work better with others around, so not having this has definitely made completing assignments and time management harder. I also miss friends a lot, but on the other hand, I feel less anxious to ask different people for help. It is much easier for me to sign up and connect with a professor in office hours for 15min, and meet with someone at the Academic Resource Center. I also started therapy at CAMHS, finally! I think this may be because being online has reduced my extra-curricular load a bit or that I am now a more confident upperclassmen, but a main factor is that events just feel a lot more accessible to me for some reason. So I would say online and in-person come with different challenges and I wouldn't say I'm doing better online than in-person, just trying different things.
column41: not sure :(. hard to answer when these decisions affect a lot of people. I really miss study and dining spaces though, but only if absolutely safe.
column46: My living situation back home is not ideal for focusing on school, but if Harvard denies on-campus students the COVID grant, then I'm not sure.
column48: Give FGLI on-campus students the $5k grant.
column115: Give FGLI students the $5,000 next semester and the semester after that if there is any sense of non-normalcy still. It was extremely unfair for Harvard to make students choose between mental and academic wellbeing and $5,000 for those who stayed home despite less than ideal home circumstances. I personally stayed home in Fall 2020 for the money and hit rock bottom mentally and did the worst I've done academically, so I decided to move on-campus for Spring 2021 despite needing the money. I took on an extra campus job (so I now work two jobs) to make up for it. Taking a LOA was not an option for me, again because of the money.

I am living on campus and it's been extremely difficult doing my schoolwork/all activities in 1 bedroom. i cannot concentrate often. i also applied for the laundry grant and books fund and received neither despite being on full financial aid. i've also gone to events in which they said they would reimburse me for food and did not. 
i'm also having technical issues with my laptop (since last semester) and harvard also refuses to provide any aid. this has all been really disappointing. 
my professors have been pretty accommodating this semester which i really appreciate (im in hist+lit and am also taking classes in the hist and tdm departments). however, i am still having to deal with the adboard for having failed a class last semester which is very frustrating and stressful to have to continue to worry about this semester. i think it's ridiculous that covid is going on and they are still forcing me to submit documentation explaining why i failed a class. 
the testing cadence is fine. crimson clear is also fine. im okay with the guest policy as well.
column9:
the wellness days are not helpful because either way we have loads of schoolwork. i would much rather have all professors decrease their workload overall. there should also be no hard deadlines. there should also still be universal pass or at least sat/unsat. we are still in a pandemic!!!

column11: I would like to be back on campus, and I would like more concrete expectations about what sorts of rules there would be (obviously things can always change, but I feel like there was very little guidance going into this semester about what we could expect as far as which color we'd be in; this made me reluctant to be on campus this semester).
column31:
As mentioned previously, I would like more concrete expectations about what sorts of rules there would be (obviously things can always change, but I feel like there was very little guidance going into this semester about what we could expect as far as which color we'd be in; this made me reluctant to be on campus this semester).

column42: I would advise against sacrificing academic opportunities for social (non-academic opportunities), with the exception of being able to interact in a minimal way with some people, like my blocking group or a subset of my blocking group. column9: It seems as though Harvard could have invited more students on campus without risking the health of its community.  Furthermore, the process for petitioning to return to campus was unclear: many first-years were allowed to return on the basis of very tenuous claims of learning-environment issues.  Harvard ought to have made the criteria for petitioning clearer, as well as their process of evaluating petitions.
column14:
First-year students have been set back somewhat in the concentration-choosing process.  Unlike previous classes, we have not been able to gain an informal understanding of departments' atmospheres, priorities, and characteristics, an understanding which seems to have been important to many upperclassmen's decision processes.  It would be helpful, as we enter into our sophomore year, to be provided with additional supports in the concentration-choosing process.
It would also be helpful to many of us if we were offered social opportunities similar to those provided to first-year students in normal years.  Many members of our class, especially international students, have not been able to make many connections among their peers, and sophomore year will be an opportunity for them to make up for lost time.

column169: I hated online classes and my house is not conducive to online courses (poor wifi in my room, nine siblings, parents' preschool in the house). Also, my grandma was dying from cancer and my grandparents seriously needed help at their home because my grandpa still works full time. I needed to be there for my family, work full time to help monetarily and drive my siblings home from school, and my online classes were simply not going to be possible for me to succeed at.
column170: See above. Same reasons now as in the fall. My fam still needs me and my classes would still be online. Also, I've loved my job!

column8: I feel that I have not been able to enjoy the spring semester to the fullest because a lot of my courses have been assigning a lot of work (much more than the previous semester) and/or not adjusting their course rules to accommodate the difficult times for some students (such as allowing one problem set drop). On top of this, many students have things to do besides doing schoolwork, such as taking time off for themselves to relax, destress, take care of themselves and their families, and spend time with their family members. However, despite the fact that remote students are living at home, because of the incredibly strenuous workload (considering that this is Harvard students doing the work) I feel students haven't been getting enough of this familial connection, let alone connections with friends. If my workload was a bit easier, and I could genuinely enjoy taking the classes I want without sacrificing my time and emotional well-being, I would rate the spring semester as a huge success. However, I don't mean to say that it has been horrible. It has been great and I wam very grateful for everyone and everything this semester.
column9: I would have adjusted the course workload and made professors and teaching staff reconsider leaving their syllabi and course requirements unadjusted for the remote pandemic times.
column14: I think that focus and time allocation for courses has been more difficult than it would have been if we were living in pre-pandemic times. I think that some students' mental wellbeing has been deteriorating, and for those already going through emotional distress (such as anxiety) I have found that having a supporting community of friends, professors, and family has been crucial. I hope that Harvard makes more efforts to allow students (even the most introverted ones) foster closer relationships with their academic surroundings and offer support to those that really need it.
column15: Luckily, I found my closest friend group within the first few weeks of school, despite the fact that we were all remotely learning. Perhaps this is what pulled us closer to each other. So, I don't think I had trouble finding a blocking group. However, being part of multiple remote-students chats, I definitely felt the tension among the other students (especially international students) around blocking season. People were having trouble finding friends because the only time we were able to see each other and interact was during zoom classes and even then, there was no time to socially interact. I think especially for international students this was burdensome because many are located in distant time zones and simply getting to some classes was hard, so taking time off to socially interact outside of classes was even harder. Although I am not an international student, I definitely sympathize with my international and remote fellows and want to give all a pat on the back for trying, including Harvard.
column31: I would like to have families be invited and able to help with move-in and come visit for family weekend. Additionally, I think that having classes conclude before Thanksgiving would be an incredible change and I highly support it, even if that means taking finals remotely. This I think allows for students to have something to look forward to as opposed to a long weekend where the majority of students won't be able to or afford to travel back home.
column32: Extension of grading basis change, remote/hybrid office hours
column46: COVID-19 and vaccination
column115: Because the tuition was not adjusted to reflect remote learning, having that $5,000 helped my family make paying for the semester more affordable. Additionally, having that $5,000 allowed for my family to buy certain things like desktops for my household, which proved to be useful investments.

column8: There is little to no campus life, which is sad, and slightly unexpected in comparison to the fall. In the fall, the FYSC, university, and proctors/PAFs definitely did more to try to create a community, but this year, it is definitely more up to ourselves.
column9: I would try to have limited dining hall seating, socially distanced, and you could reserve a spot to go get lunch-- or, just the option to pick it up. I would also try to put the fun chairs, etc. back within the science center (Cabot Library) and keep them socially distanced. Having some university sponsored yard activities would be nice too. If Harvard allowed us to "check out" sports equipement to use in the yard, like frisbees, soccer balls, etc. that would be nice too.
column14: Harvard's academics online has adjusted fairly well. I do believe there are missed opportunities as a result of online learning: for example, I am a STEM concentrator, and as a first year, I am supposed to be learning the fundamentals of lab experimentation and research. Instead, I only do online modules which are hard to mirror the realities of lab. Too, an in-class environment is hard to mirror. I feel confident about my academics regardless. I am fairly ready to choose a concentration in the Fall; but when we return to an in-person model, I hope they allow my class the opportunity to participate in freshman activities since we missed out (i.e. freshman convocation, potentially housing day, etc.).
column15: I found it helpful to reach out to online sources and read about the houses, as well as talk to proctors about blocking and its overview. If I could change anything, I would allow one or two days post blocking day where our key cards work for the house we got into, so we can tour it a little.
column31: Seating in the dining hall! Access to music rooms more than once a week! Library use for study groups! Reopening of the Smith and Science Center (especially the upper levels of the Smith center)! Make the mail center also open on weekends, and the ability for us to get our mail not within our specified time by our last names!
column32: The greater use of technology in the classroom: I like using iPads, etc. to take assessments on, and having a window to complete assessments, rather than a specified time and date.
column35: I do feel like I have learned a lot, regardless of it being in an online or in-person format.

column8: I came to this school for the people and the education. So far, all I've gotten is depression and a bill that hasn't been worth it at all.
column9: Like this semester, we should be fully operational and open!
column13: How should we know?
column31: Students should not be restricted from travel. Masks should be mandatory in some places like dining halls but not everywhere. Socialization with other driven people is the primary reason many of us chose this school, and so far the school has completely disregarded students' needs. Offering more mental health counseling is a TERRIBLE solution and just insulting. If I'm depressed and overworked, taking time out of work and what little socialization is possible to sit with someone is just another useless time suck. Harvard needs to care about its students. When will the school understand that it's hurting its reputation by hurting its students to preserve its stature, not salvaging its respect.
column32: WELLNESS DAYS ARE TERRIBLE. WE NEEDED MORE DAYS OFF AND SPRING BREAK NOT LESS BREAK AND MORE OPTIONAL OFFICE HOURS DAYS. Whoever came up with that policy has clearly not been in college for 50 years and does not understand students. All you did was hurt us further. So far I've spent more time in class/OH/sections--all optional to be fair--on wellness days than on normal days simply because its finally a chance to try to catch up a tiny bit on how fast the school moves. What happened to the promising of not having homework or assignments due after them too? Thoroughly disappointed with Harvard overall and would warn applicants how little the school cares after you've padded its admissions statistics.
column35: First, the professors prefer to share their opinions and viewpoints more than facts. That's a rampant issue with or without the pandemic. Second, how on earth can the school justify raising tuition for a lower quality of education??? Lecturers prefer to teach in a way that keeps the style consistent for them but learning through a screen is vastly worse than speaking to a person. For example, Joe is universally beloved, but his lecture style caters only to pure auditory learners and online this had been extremely frustrating. For classes like 110/111 and others, it can often not even be worth going to lecture since you cannot learn anything without reading a differently written textbook or speaking with a TF.
column38: How is this even a question? Learning is primarily a communal activity--at least it's more efficient that way--so sitting at home alone staring at a screen for 16-18 hours a day is terrible. My eyes hurt, my brain hurts, and my will to sit here and listen has dropped dramatically. If I could go back, I'd withdraw without hesitation or if going further maybe even choose a different school.
column40: Duh? The school did nothing for sophomores. Raising tuition and giving us a free online class over the summer? The last thing I want to do is be online more. I'm an extremely social person, and I have never been more depressed and overwhelmed in my life. Harvard did this to me. Harvard chose to take my drive, passion, work ethic, social skills, etc. and throw it down the drain.
column41: SOCIAL. OPPORTUNITIES. No, I don't mean having specific events or leaving a common room open every few days after its been cleaned. Kids should be allowed to socialize if they want to and allowed to choose to stay holed up if they so choose. Students should control their level of safety and restriction, not the school. Prioritize student control and open the school entirely. Dining halls, common rooms, and libraries should be open as normal.
column42: Full on campus capabilities and completely open.
column44: Will we be online? Will it be as painful as the past year has been? If on campus, will we actually have freedom or be locked up like the first years were this fall? I will not allow myself to be miserable again.
column46: What is this? Everyone wants to be around people. I understand there are extenuating circumstances; I've dealt with that pain and self-restriction due to family circumstances. I will do what I can to attempt to achieve some sense of normalcy or not enroll.

column48: Maybe not charge more tuition? I was off campus paying for on campus students' experience. That's painful and wrong. The school should help students financially, not extort them.
column106: I spend time in class, OH, rewatching lectures, or otherwise in an academic setting every day DESPITE WELLNESS DAYS. column113: Numbers are approximate, but I spend an unhealthy amount of time online every day. Why? Because I have to for school, and it's the only way to socialize. I am ready to choose my concentration but I know many people are still very unsure - I knew what I wanted to do coming into college so it is not as difficult for me. I am a bit nervous about returning to in-person classes. I think it may be helpful to have discussions with upperclassmen on what differs with in-person classes, as well as a tutorial on where classrooms are because I honestly have no idea!

column8: I feel that most of Harvard's reopening phase has been extremely reasonable. Up until last week, I would have said Extremely Satisfied. My only complaint is that there was no phase between Lime and Green, even though massive jumps take place between the two. Despite extremely low undergraduate cases on campus, we have not been able to sit in our dhall for more than 2 hours a day, and it excludes weekends. We can't go to Lamont. We can't go anywhere to study without booking in advance (some as early as 2 business days). Finally, the college's decision to cancel graduation is very hard to grapple with. We don't understand why no on-campus graduation ceremony could have been attempted: even if it was no guests and just by house. We really hope the college will come around to do something of the sort, especially given that we will likely be vaccinated. This lack of continued progression as time passes has been my biggest complaint.
column9: I would have added a phase between Lime and Green, and some way to better access the dining halls
column12: I would want to see an effort made to bring as much of us together as possible. A few events and place for us to stay. I'm not really sure how they can replicate a regular graduation but I hope they put in alot of effort and keep our experience in mind. Naturally, they have had to prioritize safety for the last year and that has been at the expense of our experience, and I really hope they make an effort to prioritize experience when they can.
column31: no opinion. I think people who enrolled during the remote semester should be prioritized. Also because they tend to engage in more unsafe activities. I also don't like the inability to swipe into other buildings. I wish I could go to my friends dorm as normal once we enter the phase where it is allowed.

column31:
The dining halls need to be open--otherwise Harvard can't be said to have done anything to reopen.

The libraries and labs need to be fully open with as absolutely few restrictions as possible and a presumption that access will be allowed in person to all materials (even those that are now on Hathi trust, for example.). These research resources are crucial for students, especially those of us who will be thesising.
column35: The teachers have been heroes.  However, I have taken mostly quite small seminar classes in which everybody's camera is on and there is some sense of community even over Zoom.

column46: I hope to live on campus because that really is the proper Harvard experience.  However, I am from Boston, and live close by--if the dining halls and libraries do not open there will not be a compelling case for me to return.

column31: If there must be some COVID-19 restrictions I am okay with mandatory masks and testing, and with limits to capacities in large lectures, but I really hope the college allows in-person extracurricular events and performances (with live audiences, even if these audiences must be distanced in some way). I really hope that Harvard does not neglect the needs of performing arts students, who have been severly hurt by virtual college. Allowing in-person social events would also allow students to meet new students and have casual conversations with others in a way that is significantly easier than what is possible with Zoom.
column32: I suppose having some virtual office hours could increase the ease of making it to such office hours, but I would definitely want to still have in-person office hours too. column8: I am very grateful to be on campus and receive housing this semester. It has been wonderful for my mental health and happiness to be around other students and the Harvard buildings again, even in this pared-down state. While I am certainly tired of online classes and wish for more transparency about the coming fall, I am overall really impressed by the way the college has handled things.
column9: I wish there was better enforcement for Wellness Days. Obviously, I miss spring break but I understand why it couldn't happen this semester. I think Wellness days were a reasonable solution in theory, and my professors are mostly good about observing them, but I know this is not the case universally.
column11: In person classes, in person graduation, and in person activities. Basically, as much normalcy as we can possibly have (which seems reasonable if everyone is vaccinated).
column31: In person classes for all small/medium size classes. In person activities; not just sports, but also music, art, and other meeting places. Music was a huge part of my life at Harvard, and it is simply not replicable online. Dining halls reopened! Ability to travel more than 10 miles away on the weekends.
column32: Zoom office hours are sometimes helpful in terms of accessibility (especially living in the quad). I love the iPads, and I love that we each get a microwave/freezer in our room (maybe in the future there could be one per suite?)
column35: I just really enjoyed all of my classes this year! I think my professors did a good and thoughtful job figuring out how to transfer their classes online. column42: I would love to see efforts by the University to help upperclassmen form connections with underclassmen, given that we will have been very fragmented by class.

column8: This semester I chose to stay home, as the pandemic had been worsening and I was on campus in the Fall. I find that home is not a great place in terms of keeping focused and satisfied with my work; it is easy to get distracted, become disinterested in my work, and hard to keep motivated. The many small facets of the college experience, quick interactions, studying on campus, etc. are missing, harming the experience as whole.
column9: I believe that the reopening plan could not solve the issues I highlighted, as they are more based in the pandemic than the college's specific opening. However, I do believe that the college should try to fix these problems next semester as the pandemic cools down and vaccines are distributed widely.
column14:
I think online learning has introduced me to Harvard academics in a helpful manner, but it does feel lacking in comparison to what a proper experience in lecture halls and in-person sections would have provided. I think I grasp what I need to, but I think I would become more motivated if I was able to engage in-person instead of over a screen. I think I am fairly ready to select a concentration, though that is because I had my interests already when I came here -- if I didn't, I would probably be more uncertain.

As we move to being in-person, it would be helpful to get a chance to acclimate to navigating campus normally, as I never got to do that. Additionally, I would probably have to learn more about using resources such as the libraries and common rooms for my work and studying.
column15:
The virtual semester caused me to disengage with interaction at fundamental levels -- I found socializing to be a chore and not remotely enjoyable. Thus, I found it incredibly difficult to create connections, and I chose to block on my own for simplicity's sake.

I believe that these issues are from the pandemic and how my mind operates; in a normal semester, these issues would be less severe or not exist at all. If things remain virtual for some reason, I cannot think of how to solve those sorts of problems.
column31: I believe that occasional testing may be warranted and it may be good for people to wear masks if they go to large gatherings or experience flu symptoms. I also personally believe that those who want to go on campus should be vaccinated for COVID-19, though I imagine that would stir up some controversy. I think it is worth it for safety on campus for next semester.
column32: I think it is helpful to have some meetings online, and they would be less tiresome when they occur far less frequently. They are convenient, especially when you may be tight on time or feeling unwell. I think it would be good to keep the extensions for pass/fail decisions as well.
column46: I believe that I would find my schooling experience much more enjoyable on campus than at home. It would help my mental health and my studies. I can also move beyond any issues at my home when I'm on campus and focusing on my work.
column47: I think that, when traveling, precautions should be taken to protect student athletes from any viral spread until we know most states have handled COVID-19 well.
column48: Students with financial challenges will likely still be facing those challenges come the fall, as the pandemic would still be cooling down then. column52: I think the school should try to return to normal within reason. Depending on how the pandemic progresses, it may have to use fewer or more precautions to keep students safe. The University should work to help Sophomores and First-Years acclimate to normal learning at the same time and restore the normal Harvard experience while remaining safe.

column8: I don't think Wellness Days have been taken very seriously in courses. The time commitment for courses has increased, with more Zoom meetings being added for some of my courses this semester than previous semesters. This has increased my screen time significantly in a way that has not been productive to my wellness.
column9: I would've released the decision earlier. Part of the reason I didn't petition to be on campus was because I didn't know enough about the plans for campus life this semester. If I had known more information about the plan and about the different color levels, I would've probably petitioned to be on campus. I would've considered including a perhaps 2-3 day ‚Äúspring break‚Äù in addition to the Wellness Days. I would've better enforced the policies in regards to Wellness Days to professors and teaching staff.
column13: A few days, or maybe a ‚ÄúHouse Orientation Week‚Äù, before classes start. We could move in a few days early and be able to replicate some of the House activities we missed due to having a remote Housing Day and being away from campus for so long.
column31: Please invite sophomores (or the original class of 2023) back to campus! We have been away from campus for an incredibly long amount of time, and effects that I could manage to push through during the Spring 2020 and Fall 2020 semesters are becoming very difficult to manage at this point. I'd also love to see time for students to settle in and reunite with their friends before classes start. Many people will not have seen their friends in over a year. I would like to see study spaces open to work somewhere other than your dorm. If dining halls could be open safely to be able to eat together, that would be amazing‚Äîbut of course it depends on what Covid restrictions permit. I would also like to see the athletic center open for use.
column35: I think I have academically learned everything I need to, but I feel extremely burnt out. Courses are also very hard to keep focus in. I feel Zoom-fatigued, since I think there are too many initiatives to meet with people and have more class meetings, but they are adding to the Zoom-fatigue such that extracurriculars are becoming unenjoyable because they're just another Zoom meeting to get on.
column38: Keeping focus during classes is very difficult. I have been significantly more burnt out during online semesters. Sometimes the burn out makes the material less enjoyable to learn. The pressure to get very high grades has been even harder with remote courses, and I have developed test anxiety due to stress and the difficulty of managing stress effectively through online format.
column40: I rarely see people my age, and that has weighed on me very much. I see a friend (from home because most of my college friends live too far away) maybe once a month or once ever two months. Because of this, I have very few reliable ways to express myself socially and relieve some of my emotions that only people my age would understand and be able to help with.
column41: Ways in which we can interact with friends that we haven't seen in over a year. Study spaces, etc. open to more than one person, even if it's just open for no more than 3-4 people.
column42: Current sophomores (original class of 2023) should absolutely be highly considered for fall 2021 planning, since they are one of the classes that have missed out the most on the Harvard experience, and spent the least time on campus.
column46: I have been away from campus for too long, and it is starting to affect my social and emotional health.
column47: Try to make Fall 2021 varsity sports possible in any way they can!
column51: I would prefer May 31, but I understand that circumstances with the vaccine could change for the better such that a more informed decision would be available a few weeks later by June 15.
column52: A Fall Break, or a much more enforced version of Wellness Days, would be very useful to help relieve some of the Zoom fatigue and academic burn out from previous semesters.
column113: The time spent on coursework has been abysmal. It is exhausting to spend that much time on coursework in your room all alone, every single day, for 10 hours a day. At least on campus that time was broken up by spontaneous conversations with friends, studying with friends, or other daily activities. Being remote, however, there is nothing to break up the time spent doing coursework, and it has even altered my views on how academic success relates to my personal values/worth‚Äîsince all I do is academic work now, I feel like I have attached it to my worth in unhealthy ways.

column118: Communicate student perspectives on remote learning with professors and teaching staff. I think there are some aspects of remote learning that, no matter how hard we students try, are not getting across to our professors.
column161: I have enjoyed living with my family, but managing my family/home life with school has been extremely difficult. It feels like school responsibilities and family responsibilities are constantly in competition because both are very important to me, but it feels like if I neglect school for family then I fall behind in my classes and it is very difficult to get back up to speed, but if I neglect family for school, then I am failing my family.
column162: Feeling disconnected from my courses and Harvard community. Also not seeing any people/friends my age. These have been very difficult to deal with in terms of mental health.

column165: Please make special accommodations and give preference to the original class of 2023 for the Fall 2021 semester!!

column8: The handling of Wellness Days and of our concerns with respect to Wellness Days has been incredibly subpar.
column9: I would have allotted Wellness Days in such a way that maintains the original purpose of spring break: a middle-of-term break that helps to reduce stress buildup in the middle of the year. Packing the Wellness Days more densely would have been much more helpful, for instance giving us a 3, 2, or 1 day work week during the week that was supposed to be spring break and extending existing days off. Harvard has shown that they have the ability to rearrange class schedules within any given week, so Wellness Days should have always extended either a weekend or a federal holiday. The required shift in schedules by the college itself would have taken the pressure off of students to request that their professors be more mindful about assignments due near Wellness Days. I know from asking my professors that the absence of spring break has thrown usual class schedules into question as there is no specified time during which assignment due dates should get pushed back, resulting in the work from a regular semester being forced into a semester that is, for all intents and purposes, a week shorter.
column14: If anything, online learning has been a detriment to my acclimation to the rigors of Harvard academics. The gap between professors and students is, from what I can assume not having been at Harvard in a non online learning format, much larger than I would expect is normal. I feel like my academics have suffered from virtual learning because much communication between professors and students is useually through the medium of body language, allowing professors to more accurately understand what students are struggling with and to help students more accurately understand what concepts the professor is trying to present. Online learning prevents this vital form of communication and makes the classes at Harvard worth much less than they are in non virtual years.
column15: I would make it more obvious that it is okay to block in a single group and that it is okay to leave blocking groups if they do not work out for any individual. Virtual learning has prevented much interaction that is necessary in deciding who you will most likely live with or near for the next 3 years.
column31: Tessting in a regular schedule for those not vaccinated and a large scale push for vaccination.  The amount of money spent on covid tests could be spent on procuring vaccines for those students not already vaccinated.
column32: I know I speak for many when I say I would abhor the continuation of Wellness Days and early move out times. A recompensation for people who took classed during the covid 19 Era equivalent to the estimated value lost in both not having in person classes and reduced opportunities.
column44: I am considering the possibility of online learning returning as a reason I might take a gap year. I do not believe the value gained from attending college for 4 contiguous years outweighs the significant value lost from virtual learning.
column46: I am on financial aid and could not afford housing in the area outside of Harvard.
column47:
Varsity sports should not be given any special consideration over that granted to the possibility 
of in person lecture classes, contact sports especially.
column48: Given that many students enrolled in the 2021 have been taking Harvard Zoom classed for a year or more, students in and off campus should be given substantial compensation for the drop in quality of classes. Absolutely no one who is living off campus should be required to pay for a meal plan or for housing and other expenses of that nature. More financial aid should be given than usual as many families whose income during covid will not yet be fully reflected in their financial aid.
column51: There is never any certainty that perdictions will hold, no matter when they are made.
column52: I think that Harvard should absolutely not implement Wellness days.

column9: Letting sophomores come back. I live alone in the quad because my blockmates couldn't come and it can be pretty isolating.
column13: I think if we got all the house traditions we missed that would make up for it. Sorry to say but virtual retreat was not it. I don't know anyone in my house.
column31: I think a hybrid model is pretty silly in general. Everyone should be on campus but consistency matters so I think either all classes should be offered in person and recorded for students who don't feel safe attending in person, or they should all be online. Clubs should be able to meet in person if they want regardless because we still would have regular testing and the groups are generally small. If classes are online, live attendance shouldn't be required bc zoom fatigue is real and even if I sleep through a lecture I'm not wasting another hour of my life rewatching it so I'd rather just watch it on my own time without penalty. I think online office hours are still a good option regardless of the pandemic. We should still do the initial quarantine to isolate covid cases coming in, but I think we should be able to use spaces in a somewhat normal capacity or at least not have limits on in suite gatherings. We should not require vaccinations unless harvard is distributing them bc not every student has access.
column32: Hand sanitizer should be everywhere always. Office hours should be offered virtually for convenience. All lectures should be recorded even if we are in person.
column35: If we're being honest I wasn't really learning anything anyway. At least this way professors expect less and have open note exams and you have a better chance of better grades
column36: Online learning and in-person learning are equally challenging
column38: Both have their issues. In person is hard bc class is generally hard and assignments are generally harder and lectures aren't always recorded so if you missed something you missed it. Online is hard bc there are so many other factors like no work life balance, zoom fatigue, health problems that come with being more sedentary, a lack of motivation, etc. In person classes are hard bc school is hard while online classes are hard bc life is hard.
column40: Being with my friends. I'm a sophomore and haven't seen my friends in a year. By the time fall 2022 comes around it will have been 1.5 years. I've been away from them way longer than I've been with them and since my friends were the main reason I chose to go to harvard, my experience here has generally sucked and my social life is going to the river once a week bc everyone is busy and no one I know lives in the quad. And that's just the spring semester when I actually had access to some people. Fall semester was only not miserable because of the $5000 so I was actually able to leave and live with some people that I could have some level of social interaction with.
column41: In person club meetings and gatherings with reasonable capacity limits (I understand not letting 500 people be in a room but 8 is a really small number)
column46: I'm poor and live on campus for free

column51: A later decision is probably better because the closer to the start of school the better they can estimate how the covid situation will be and the less likely they are to make a decision that is overly limiting. However, I'd rather scramble to plan for in person with a late decision than settle for virtual because a decision was made too early and erring too far on the side of caution

column113: Ngl I really don't do my work and my screen time is terrible. I only really see people on Fridays but I FaceTime people a lot.

I think realistically it doesn't make sense to give a $5000 stipend to ppl for no reason other than they did it before, but again, I think the start up grant was really helpful freshman year and it would be nice if everyone on full aid, regardless of year, received it. column137: Living off campus was good because I was in a new city with people I didn't know and it was an opportunity I would have never gotten in other circumstances and for once I wasn't poor and could focus on school instead of working too. I'm dealing with all the same home life problems and more, but this time I don't have as much money and I don't have people to make the experience better. column9:
They should let people have overnight guests if they're also on campus. It's crazy that at pretty much every level people can go to indoor restaurants in the square with a bunch of strangers who aren't tested regularly, while unless we're in green we're not allowed to have overnight guests who are also being tested 3 times a week. We're allowed to have a person on campus in our room all day long if we want. It's not going to make a difference and it's not going to increase anyone's risk of getting covid if that same person stays overnight. This has personally put me in unsafe situations because I've had to walk back from the quad at 2 am by myself as a woman. There are no longer shuttles available and the evening van stops way earlier than it used to. Either make it easier to travel safely between different parts of campus or just let people have overnight guests who are also on campus because it's truly not going to make any difference. 

There should be more of an emphasis on sustainability in the dining hall. 

More study spaces should be open and you should be able to reserve spaces less than 2 days in advance.
column11: It should be as normal as possible. We will all be vaccinated by then, so I expect that we will be able to function normally.

column8: Since I am off campus, I cannot attest to the on campus procedural changes, but I have heard that they are good. For off campus students, to me, this semester seems like a repeat of virtual senior year of high school with more time on Zoom and on technology and a harder workload with no ‚Äúcollege feel‚Äù and limited socialization.
column9: Since I was an off campus first year, I did not really have an opportunity to experience the Spring 2021 reopening plan, so I do not have a foundation to evaluate the reopening plan.
column14:
I had attended a college preparatory high school, so I thought I was somewhat prepared for college. However, the online learning modality was difficult for me because of the enormous amount of screen time. It is not only classes, but the homework, problem sets, labs, and essays were all online and as a result, my body shut down and it was extremely difficult. 
I know in person learning was not an option this year, but I think it would have been easier in person to handle the work load and not have to do everything over a screen. I don't think the work load was the problem, it was the screen time. 
I went to many office hours for the concentration events, so I feel relatively confident about the direction of my academics at Harvard. I am worried as a potential life sciences concentrator that the online labs would not prepare me for in person labs.
column15: The blocking process was like something I had never experienced. I had heard that the process was dramatic, so to avoid conflict, I blocked as a single. I also did not feel like I knew people well enough to block with them for the rest of my college career.
column31:
Rising sophomores will be given an equal chance of living on campus for both semesters because of the limited first year experience. Hopefully, all undergraduate students will be able to live on campus.
I was deprived of the opportunity to live in first year housing as a freshman and felt a disconnection with my peers living in the Yard. I will hopefully develop better connections with my house peers, but feel like it is necessary to be on campus to foster these relationships.
column46: I would like to live on campus if possible because I was only on campus for Fall 2020 and it was a limited college experience at best. I want to feel like I am part of the Harvard community and at times I question if I actually am.
column48: Understanding that this has been a difficult time for every student and making their decisions based on the needs of the students.
column51: It would be nice to know earlier, but the situation is rapidly changing and I would rather have a decision that is relatively stable than an early decision that changes before going to campus and find out that I am not invited back to campus

column8: I've set my expectations lower since there's a pandemic going on. Given the circumstances, I'm not too picky about how things are going. I think that zoom classes are as fine as they could be, except for classes/sections that run over 2 hours; being online for long periods of time is not ideal for anyone. I think that there are some interesting events that are put on to try to connect people, so I think there's effort to make the semester as good as it can be.

I think that I'm learning what I would have otherwise, but I don't feel like I'm living the full college experience (obviously) since it's all online. I'm very ready to choose a concentration in the fall based on my academic experiences thus far.

I think the blocking process is fine; it's how people approach it that can cause problems.

column8: Studying remotely, it's been very isolating. Without friends or other classmates in town, I have felt quite lonely and this has contributed to feelings of depression and hopelessness. My family is working, so I don't have in person contact for nearly the entire day, and with everything virtual, I live in front of a screen. Having strictly followed all guidelines and restrictions in the fall, I did not have the opportunity to form close friendships because I could not visit other dorms and only met up with a few friends to go to a restaurant outside campus occasionally. This was and continues to be emotionally and mentally distressing.
column14: While I have adjusted to some courses, I feel that I am left less prepared in others (in particular, courses that typically involve labs). Since I have had no hands-on experience this year, I am uncertain about what exactly my concentration of interest entails.

A video/presentation that can be easily accessed could be helpful too.

column32: Class material available online/via Canvas, readily available hand sanitizing stations, more services available both online and in-person (e.g., counseling/mental health services), some Wellness Days so that the year is more spread out (but ensuring professors take them seriously), not adding a fall break because this would cram class material

column48: For students who may prefer to be on campus due to learning environment needs, a stipend would be alleviating. Many FGLI students this year chose to stay home despite it being a bad learning environement because of the $5,000/financial necessities. Don't encourage FGLI students to choose between supporting their family and having a good learning environment. Offering FGLI students more health insurance this/next year also seems particularly helpful.
column51: It would be helpful to have the decision by the time students have to move out since it might impact summer plans.
column52: Maybe flexibility with grading deadlines/changes (similar to this semester's April 5th extension)
column115: During the fall semester, I chose to stay home because of the financial help the $5,000 stipend provided. This was despite the fact that my learning environment was not ideal. It was hard, and I ultimately petitioned for spring housing because I didn't feel like I could make it through another semester of working/studying from home/in those circumstances. This stipend should continue, but FGLI students who choose to be on campus due to learning environment needs should still receive at least a portion of the stipend. This will encourage FGLI students to prioritize their learning rather than financial needs.

column8: Besides wellness days, everything else has been pretty great I would say. column9: As I'm living pretty far away off campus, I haven't paid much attention to what's been going on in terms of specific reopening plans.
column14: I honestly have no idea if I'm ready for the rigors of Harvard academics, because I have no year of normal college to compare this one to. I feel like I've been doing a decent job managing things and it feels like I have the resources to craft a concentration plan over the coming months, but I have no clue how balancing in-person life and academics will actually go. Frankly, I'm expecting a bit of a drop-off in my performance, simply because it feels like I have a little too much time on my hands now.
column15: I personally didn't have any issues, but I know from friends it gave some people serious grief. column31: I think the most important thing for me would be continued testing. That gave me the greatest sense of security about the semester.

column14: I am ready to choose a concentration in the Fall. I think online learning did a decent job in acclimating me to the rigors of Harvard academics. It'd be helpful for first-years to have the option to watch the incoming freshman orientation videos since we didn't really get to use all of the resources the first year and it might make incoming sophomores who haven't physically been on the Harvard Campus more mentally prepared. It'd also be nice to have access to some first year resources because some of us might feel like freshmen next year.

column8: I understand the limitations of the current situation and appreciate Harvard's attempts to work within those limits. Nevertheless, another semester with limited opportunities to truly interact with other students and another semester of virtual classes is not ideal for learning, both within the classroom and without.
column9:
I would have liked more opportunities for people to spend time with others in a non-virtual setting, even if it is outside, with masks, at a social distance.

Also, the Wellness Days was a good idea in theory, but it was not equivalent to a Spring Break in practice. Many classes still had meetings/office hours that were "optional" but recommended, and even if they weren't, most students would likely feel obligated to attend anyways, since it's only one day. A longer stretch of days off does much more to give students a mental break.
column11: In-person classes and more chances to get face time with other students, even with covid-appropriate measures.
column31: In-person classes, to the fullest (yet safest) extent of Harvard's ability
column32:
The virtual classes are obviously not ideal, because the nature of Zoom limits academic engagement/discussion between students. Zoom fatigue and eye fatigue due to hours of staring at a screen are also real issues.

Beyond that, the virtual shopping week experience is not as exciting, informative, or convenient as a real shopping week where you can literally drop in and "shop" a class instead of having to sign up for every single class you are considering.

Finally, as soon as possible, please give us back the Spring Break! Wellness Days just can't compare...
column35: Virtual classes cannot compare in terms of discussion/debate with peers, which is a great part of how I learn. There is also less interaction/participation in general with Zoom classes, through no fault of the professors'.

column8:
I think that it's good that the school has finally adapted many of its programs to work for an online environment, and that more professors have made themselves more proficient and adapted their classes to cause less zoom fatigue.
As someone that is on campus, I am also happy with the updated rules regarding having people over and common spaces that are available to groups of students. I absolutely hate the wellness days and think they are pointless and don't allow for any respite. I always have work to catch up on these days and a few of my classes have recorded lectures and things assigned for these days. The work load stays the same for each week which means I can burn out around the wellness day or just treat it like a normal day with my same amount of work.
column9: I would have allowed for a spring break of some sort, and perhaps focused more on mental wellness accessibility. Where is this other money going? Spend it on more therapy resources and such, and make it easier for the students that are struggling specifically in a way that makes it so that they can't really reach out.
column12: I don't care at all about the alumni pandering for money, which is what it seems like Commencement is actually for instead of being a graduation ceremony. I understand that Harvard needs this alumni resource, but it would be nice for the make up to actually be about the seniors that graduated.

column32: Figure out the plan and specifics before students are on campus, also have a clearer set of expectations when it comes to public transport/etc because some aspects of that seem to go against the logic of restrictions in place on campus.
column35: There is less community that can be fostered, and it seems like there is more busy work that takes away from free time to be able to try and get a better connection to professors and other students. I have to do my classes on here, and I have to do my work on here so I can turn it in, there has been minimal access to printers, so even long readings are done on my computer. It's insane!

column14: I think my transition from high school to college has actually been pretty smooth. My schedule is about the same in terms of schoolwork, or if anything I have more free time in college. Academics are a little harder and might require more effort, but I think I'm managing it well. I also felt that I've been able to explore my interests more in my first year, even through the relatively few electives I've taken, so I have a better sense of what I might want to secondary in (my planned concentration hasn't changed).
column15: Having my proctor and advisor remind us of deadlines and steps in the process was useful both as an introduction to blocking and the actual tasks we had to do.
column31: For the Houses, I think there should be as much a return to normal as there can for dormmates, but similar to this past year on campus, people should be as spread out as they can be - e.g. more singles, try to avoid shared bathrooms and limit to common space. If there aren't enough rooms to accommodate that many more singles for the returning classes, then require more frequent cleaning of living spaces, bathrooms, etc.
column32: Even not in COVID times, more frequent cleaning (in private and public spaces) definitely wouldn't hurt. This is my first year so I don't know what it was like pre-COVID, but I also found the grab-and-go meals in the dining hall to be convenient (when I was on campus in the fall).

column8: I am at home and haven't really enjoyed it.
column9: Honestly, even though I am not really happy with my personal outcome, I am not sure that I would have changed much.
column14: I don't really know how rigorous in person academics are, so I can't really speak to the first question. I am not overly confident in my academics because, though I am doing alright in class, I am a little concerned I may not be retaining information well. I do not feel very prepared to choose a concentration yet because I want to do engineering and being online has meant that I have chosen to postpone taking some introductory courses that really rely on labs to be effective. I am not sure what new challenges in person learning will bring beyond perhaps having to schedule better, but I really have appreciated having recorded lectures to look back to when reviewing so I hope those stick around even as we go back to being in person.
column15: I didn't feel like I knew anyone well enough to block with them so I would up going solo. Even though I know this is somewhat common, I wasn't really satisfied with being somewhat forced into that decision. Though I recognize that some of the blame is certainly on me for not getting out there and meeting more people, the college's decisions regarding the level to which campus was open this fall/spring certainly didn't help. I hope that this will be a problem that is somewhat unique to my year and that future first-years will be able to meet and connect with their classmates in person next fall, but if that isn't the case, I think the college needs to work harder on social events. Online zoom breakout room conversations don't really work as a way to make friends. I know circumstances made things pretty tough, but I would have appreciated some more effort and creativity in online (perhaps repeated) social events so that we would have time to build relationships with others rather than just introducing ourselves to others.
column31: Testing and quarantine on positives are good policies, but especially as it gets colder you NEED to open indoor spaces for studying and socialization. The schedule followed in the fall was quite delayed and we were lucky to have mild weather otherwise it would have been miserable. As I was not on campus this spring, I don't know if adequate corrections to the system have been made, but I really feel like there were ways to enable the in person socialization that is so much more rewarding than zoom meetings.
column32: As mentioned previously, recorded classes are fantastic studying tools and great for double checking things you may have missed in class. If it is not too big a burden on professors, please continue this practice.
column46: I really want to meet people in person. I feel like I still don't really know my Harvard community well and don't find that the online opportunities we have had work really at all.
column47: As I do not plan to play a varsity sport, I am not sure I am the best person to speak on this subject, but it is good to remember that sports do offer social and health benefits for athletes so they should be resumed if possible. That said, safety should come first and signs of COVID outbreaks are certainly a reason to halt practice/competition and ensure the safety of players.
column48: The pandemic has resulted in many people either suffering substantial cuts to their income or losing it entirely and even those who had good savings plans are likely starting to see their funds diminish rapidly. These students have suffered a lot in the past year and should certainly receive as much support as possible this upcoming fall, potentially even a stipend from the college to help their family that would otherwise potentially rely on them to take a year off and work to help with financial troubles.
column51: As a college, you have been far too slow to make announcements this year and left students feeling stressed an uncertain in already troubling times. You need to improve on this front moving forward. I believe that it is important that students know what is happening in the fall early in the summer, especially new students and first years who will have many questions beyond whether or not they will actually be able to go to college in the fall.
column52: Though I certainly understand the motivation behind the policy, entirely shutting down any form of indoor socializing was a policy that I think ultimately caused more harm than good, especially for first years who didn't really know anyone well. Zoom calls are not great for meeting people and struggle even as a way to keep up with friends. People also don't really want to be outside all of the time, especially when weather takes a turn for the worse.
