column8: Classes have been run fairly smoothly this semester, the college has provided lots of free resources to help students with a variety of things (like resume workshops, game nights, etc.), and I think overall with things like housing day, I feel more connected to the college than I did last semester. The only thing that has been disappointing is wellness days. They are not relaxing at all, and in fact the weeks with wellness days have felt significantly more difficult than those without.
column9: I would have gotten rid of wellness days and had the normal Spring break.
column14:
I think that online learning has acclimated me well to the rigors of Harvard academics. I am not 100% sure what Harvard academics looks like in a regular year, but the sense that I got from online courses is that the majority of learning (reading, watching lectures, etc) takes place on your own time, and class time is for discussions and going over some problems. I think that worked fine on Zoom. I feel fairly confident with my academics - it is definitely challenging, but there are lots of opportunities to get tutored or have people read papers, so I don't feel like there's a lack of help. I feel confident that I can get the grades I want if I put in the right amount of time and effort. 
I am about 90% ready to choose a concentration in the fall - I am pretty sure I want to do applied math, but I'm not sure exactly what the area of application will be. I am also still interested in architecture, so that interest is probably why I'm not 100% set on applied math. 
My hope is that as we return to in-person learning, we are still offered the same number of resources given to us this year to help with academics. I would love to still have access to ARC and OCS workshops, as well as online tutoring.
column15: At the beginning of the school year I was definitely scared that I wouldn't find friends to block with (especially since I have been at home both semesters), but it actually worked out pretty well. I don't think any changes need to be made for future first-year students if we completely re-open in the fall, since students will get to have the in-person, casual interactions that usually facilitate friendships (which then leads to people finding their blockmates). This year was just difficult because campus was not fully open.
column31: I would really like to see effort be put into opening up campus buildings, including libraries, the Smith Center, and dining halls, to students. It has been really tough not getting to experience any on campus life so far, and it would suck to come back to campus and not be able to meet with friends and study in those places. I want there to be appropriate safety restrictions (like wearing a mask at all times), but I also want to be able to fully utilize campus.
column32: As mentioned before, I would love to see Harvard continue to put effort into offering as many online resources as possible to students. It makes academic and social help as accessible as possible, and I think eliminating any of those things they made available because of coronavirus would be really harmful.

column48: I think Harvard should continue to offer the $5000 stipend to students who continue to face financial challenges regarding coronavirus during the Fall 2021 semester. Just because students are allowed back on campus does not mean their families will stop suffering from the effects of coronavirus (in ways that may not immediately show up on the forms used for calculating financial aid), so something should be done to offer them support.
column115: With the $5000 allowance for remote students, I was able to complete my first two semesters without paying any money, which was fantastic - my family didn't have to worry about taking out loans for my college. I think it would be fantastic if the stipend could continue (I can't say no to free money), but I'm not sure in what circumstances it would be applied if all students were invited back to campus.

column48: Support them?? Any and every student on total financial aid probably just went through the hardest year of their lives, especially if they don't have support at home. Even if they got the money, it was hard to see it cover every expense for a whole semester, especially compared to how they were living at Harvard, they did not have access to the food, home, or social connections that traditionally privileged Harvard students had since day one. Dorm life was somewhat an equalizer, because students could make friends, and build their own networks, but I'm sure if you sent out a poll and asked, mostly everyone will tell you that they didn't make new friends. Also a lot of the full financial aid kids didn't even go home I bet, or if they did, they had to start contributing to the home life in ways that richer students were not bothered with, WHILE BOTH WERE STUDYING AND GETTING THE SAME DEGREE. The playing field was just not fair, even more so than usual.

And when you wanna buy food, it comes out your own pocket, and thats money the school didn't give. At least on your own, you can choose to starve yourself at your own leisure (don't have to worry about them serving reds best catch!). And when you choose food, you can have the balance of nutrition that you actually want. Alongside with the fact that when you split a flat between friends you actually get social interaction and don't feel like you're the only person on the planet, in your one wing of the building.

column9: I would have invited less people back.
column14:
I found the academic rigor to be very intensive. I think I have adapted to the online style of learning, so I'm not sure what the experience will be like in real life. I think I am a little worried about timed sit down tests because having time to do exams in a relaxed environment, in my own privacy, with access to textbooks + more time has been very helpful. I don't know how prepared I will be for that. I am also interested in how an actual day will be like with having to move all over campus constantly for classes, sections, OH, club meetings, socializing, etc. I feel those two things may become big stresses in the future. I think there were some surprising benefits to the online model and I hope they are kept. 
I came into college knowing what I wanted to study, so I feel confident in what I want to concentrate in. I would like to study something else along with it, but I haven't narrowed that down yet though. I'm hoping through more classes I'll be able to figure it out.
column15:
Online was weird because all of the friends I had were very fragmented and it was difficult to bring them together. I think blocking is always confusing, and it's more a matter of coordinating with many different friends. I am, in the end, very very happy with how my blocking group worked out. 
For future first-years, they'll spend their full time on campus, so I think they should just make sure all of the friends they want to block with get a chance to at least meet each other.

column8: It's really disappointing that Harvard has not adopted some sort of hybrid system, as most other colleges have. This is particularly hard-hitting for STEM majors, who are falling behind their peers in regards to laboratory experience. If the COVID situation worsens again, we should still have the ability to have in-class, socially-distanced lab, because it is vital for our education.
column9: In-person lab sections. All else works reasonably well online, but the lack of lab experience is really hurting those of us who plan to pursue careers in the sciences.
column31: If we are invited on campus, we should be able to participate in in-person activities, to some extent. Otherwise, it makes no sense, especially for the bulk of international students, to come back to campus. Living costs in the US are too high for some of us to deal with if we are only online.
column32:
Online shopping week does not work well across the board. There are exceptions, wherein professors come prepared and give a lecture, which allows students to evaluate their teaching style. However, most professors only host Q&A which does not give us a good idea of how they teach and if this course will agree with us. In person shopping week was a lot more effective in this regard, and should be re-implemented when possible.
However, online OHs do work well. They allow students to listen in when others ask questions, which is very helpful to those who are uncomfortable asking questions and also helps ensure that all student questions are answered.
column35: The attitude toward international students in the beginning of the pandemic. Also, it is among the minority of schools that have not considered in-person seminars and labs thus far.
column38: Online learning makes it difficult to concentrate, provides us with less resources, and is generally far inferior to in-person classes.
